GRANT AND PROJECT SUMMARY 

Mongolia 
 
Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector  (subsector):  Water  supply  and  other  municipal  infrastructure 
and  services  (urban  sector  development,  water  supply  and 
sanitation, waste management, other municipal services)  

Themes  (subthemes):  Private  sector  development  (public–private 
partnerships),  governance 
capacity 
development  (organizational  development),  regional  cooperation 
and integration (cross-border infrastructure) 

(public  administration), 

Location impact: Urban (high impact), regional (high impact) 
 
Category  B.  Initial  environmental  examinations  were  prepared  for  all 
part  B  activities  in  accordance  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).  
 
Part  A  will  finance  consulting  services  to  support  (i)  infrastructure 
services  reforms  including  performance-based  contracts  for  urban 
services  delivery,  (ii)  institutional  development  and  capacity  building 
to strengthen urban planning and policy making, (iii) strengthening of 
regional  cooperation,  and  (iv)  project  management  and  project 
performance monitoring. 
 
Part  B  will  finance  priority  infrastructure  improvements  and  physical 
outputs  including  (i)  water  source  development,  water  transmission, 
storage,  and  distribution  network,  allowing  increased  connections  to 
piped  water  supply  and  reducing  system  leakage;  (ii)  increased 
wastewater  collection  coverage  and  enhanced  capacity 
for 
wastewater treatment and effluent reuse; (iii) improved efficiency and 
coverage  of  district  heating  services;  (iv)  improved  storm  water 
drainage; (v) surfaced central road networks; and (vi) development of 
controlled solid-waste landfills and enhanced capacity for solid-waste 
collection. 
 
The  aimags  (provinces)  of  Omnogovi  and  Dornogovi  (Southeast 
Gobi) are poised to experience a rapid increase in economic activity 
as  a  result  of  rapid  growth  in  mining  and  cross-border  trade.  The 
influx  associated  with  these  economic  activities  is  projected  to  more 
than double urban populations in the project towns by 2020. For some 
soum  (district)  centers  in  Southeast  Gobi,  population  is  expected  to 
increase by an order of magnitude by 2020.  
 
The  provision  of  urban  infrastructure  and  services  is  currently  poor 
and  is  not  keeping  pace  with  population  growth.  Many  services  are 
either inadequate or absent. There are low levels of access to water 
supply  and  sanitation,  and  smaller  urban  areas  do  not  have  piped 
networks.  Insufficient  and  unreliable  urban  services  add  to  business 
and  household  costs,  damage  the  urban  environment  and  diminish 
quality  of  life,  and  decrease  the  attractiveness  of  towns  to  further

potential  investment.  Investment  and  capacity  development  are 
required to enable government to expand the coverage and improve 
the quality and reliability of urban services. Local governments are ill-
equipped to meet the joint challenges posed by increased demand for 
scarce water resources. 
 
Maximizing the benefits to existing and future residents of Southeast 
Gobi 
trade  growth,  and  associated 
economic  development  opportunities  depends  on  effective  urban 
planning,  management,  and  service  delivery  policies  and  structures 
being  in  place.  Strengthening  the  provision  of  basic  urban  services 
will  require  institutions  and  policies  that  provide  incentives  for 
performance  while  also  ensuring  affordability.  Services  are  currently 
provided by utilities that are largely owned by local government, and 
are  delivered  at  a  loss  due  to  unwillingness  of  local  government 
councils to raise tariffs to cost-recovery levels. This is costly in terms 
of  the  resources  spent  on  untargeted  subsidies  and  foregone 
opportunities to attract private sector expertise and financing. 
 
The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  enhanced  economic  development 
and  livability  in  aimag  centers  and  mining  and  border  towns  in 
Southeast  Gobi.  The  outcome  of  the  project  will  be  improved  urban 
governance,  and  expanded  access  to  sustainable  infrastructure  and 
services in urban places in Southeast Gobi. 
 
The  total  cost  of  the  project  is  estimated  at  $21.9  million  equivalent, 
including duties and taxes of about $1.99 million.

ADB  will  provide  a  grant  of  $15  million  equivalent  from  its  Special 
Funds resources to cover 68.6% of the total project cost. Duties and 
taxes are estimated at $1.99 million. A domestic contribution of $6.90 
million  equivalent  is  required,  which  will  comprise  $6.80 million 
equivalent from the Government of Mongolia and $0.1 million in-kind 
from the participating aimag governments.  
 
The  project  will  be  implemented  over  4.5  years  beginning  in  June 
2010. The period of utilization will be up to 31 May 2015.

 iii 

Development (MRTCUD) 
 
The  MRTCUD  will  be  the  executing  agency,  supported  by  a  project 
management unit (PMU) headed by a project director. The MRTCUD 
will  be  responsible  for  strategic  guidance,  technical  supervision  and 
execution,  and  ensuring  compliance  with  grant  covenants. 
Implementation  of  the  priority  infrastructure  development  component 
(part  B)  will  be  carried  out  by  the  aimag  governments.  Project 
implementation units (PIUs) will be established in each aimag and will 
be  responsible  for  day-to-day  implementation  of  physical  works.  The 
MRTCUD  will  coordinate  the  activities  of  the  two  PIUs  at  the  aimag 
level through consultants and PMU staff, and will facilitate processing 
and approvals of designs, contracts, and other documents as required 
at  ministry  level.  The  project  director,  supported  by  the  PMU  and 
consultants,  will  coordinate  all  activities  under  the  project  and  be 
responsible for overall project execution, monitoring, and supervision. 
 
A  project  steering  committee  will  be  established  with  full  powers  to 
take  decisions  on  matters  relating  to  project  implementation.  The 
project  director  will  be  the  member  secretary  of  the  project  steering 
committee,  which  will  be  chaired  by  the  state  secretary  of  the 
MRTCUD.  Members  of  the  committee  will  include  the  chair  of  the 
State  Property  Committee;  chair  of  the  National  Development  and 
Innovation  Committee;  director  of  the  Budget  Policy  Department  of 
the Ministry of Finance; and representatives of the Ministry of Nature, 
Environment and Tourism, Ministry of Mineral Resources and Energy, 
the  MRTCUD,  and  the  aimag  governments  of  Dornogovi  and 
Omnogovi. 
 
Procurement  financed  from  the  ADB  grant  will  be  carried  out  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended 
from  time  to  time).  International  competitive  bidding  (ICB)  will  be 
applied  to  supply  contracts  estimated  to  cost  $500,000  or  more. 
Supply  contracts  with  a  value  less  than  $500,000  will  follow  national 
competitive  bidding  (NCB),  and  those  less  than  $100,000  will  follow 
shopping  procedures  as  reflected  by  particular  circumstances  of  the 
contract packages. ICB will be used for civil works contracts valued at 
$1 million or more. Civil works contracts valued at less than $1 million 
but more than $100,000 will be procured using NCB procedures. The 
selection  and  engagement  of  contractors  will  be  subject  to  ADB 
approval. Before commencement of NCB procurement, ADB and the 
recipient will review the recipient’s procurement procedures to ensure 
consistency  with  ADB 
requirements.  Any  modifications  or 
clarifications  to  the  recipient’s  procedures  will  be  documented  in  the 
procurement  plan.  Any  internationally  tendered  equipment  packages 
will  include  the  technical  support  for  ensuring  proper  installation, 
testing, commissioning, and training of operational staff as part of the 
related  contracts.  In  accordance  with  ADB  requirements,  foreign 
contractors may participate in bidding for NCB contracts.

The  project  will  directly  benefit  about  100,000  people  in  six  towns  in 
Omnogovi and Dornogovi aimags, of whom approximately 30.7% live 
line.  The  project  components  have  strong

for basic living conditions and assist in removing existing constraints 
on  social  development  and  economic  growth.  Similarly,  priority 
infrastructure improvements were designed in accordance with sound 
principles  based  on  need,  consultation  and  targeting,  and  demand 
management.  The  project  supports 
rehabilitation  before  new 
investment,  and  infrastructure  improvements  represent  technically

The  2008  joint  country  portfolio  performance  review  and  a  2008  risk 
assessment for the education and urban infrastructure sectors noted 
the key sector risks as poor capital investment and budget planning, 
underdeveloped  institutional  frameworks  and  poor  capacity,  lack  of 
monitoring  and  evaluation,  poor  procurement  integrity,  and  weak 
national  contractors.  The  proposed  project  addresses  these  risks  by 
(i)  building  national  and  local  government  investment  planning 
capacity,  (ii)  building  the  capacity  of  local  service  institutions  with 
increased  private  sector  participation,  (iii) 
institutional 
change  on  measuring  and  improving  service  delivery  performance, 
(iv)  adopting  a  design-and-build  modality  for  procurement  of  priority 
infrastructure improvements to attract better-qualified contractors, and 
(v)  combining  individual  civil  works  activities  into  larger  contract 
packages  to  generate  economies  of  scale  and  create  packages  that 
are eligible for ICB.  
 
It  is  assumed  that  anticipated  demand  for  urban  infrastructure 
services  in  the  project  towns  will  materialize,  mining  developments 
will  continue,  and  major  mining  companies  will  remain  committed  to 
forms  of  mine  development  that  support  urban  development  in 
neighboring  towns.  It  is  further  assumed  that  government  policy 
continues to allow free movement of people to the project areas. 
 
Government  policies  on  public–private  partnerships  for  the  provision 
of  municipal  services  are  central  to  project  sustainability  and 
outcomes.  It  is  assumed  that  proposed  reforms  to  service  delivery 
institutions  in  aimag  and  soum  centers  will  be  supported,  and 
contracts for operation of municipal services will proceed and will be 
supported  by  a  viable  independent  regulatory  mechanism.  It  is 
assumed that the domestic private sector will participate in operation 
management contracts for service delivery.  
 
The project does not have any particular technical risks. Conventional 
engineering  designs  with  proven  records  of  reliable  performance  are 
adopted  for  water  supply,  wastewater  management,  solid-waste 
management,  and  roads.  The  proposed  packaging  of  priority 
infrastructure  improvements  under  part  B  will  provide  for  contracts 
that qualify for ICB and attract better-qualified contractors.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to Mongolia for the Southeast Gobi Urban and Border Town Development Project. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
  

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
The  aimags  (provinces)  of  Omnogovi  and  Dornogovi  (Southeast  Gobi)  are  poised  to 
experience a rapid increase in economic activity as a result of (i) planned development of new 
mines  at  Tavan  Tolgoi,  Oyu  Tolgoi,  and  Tsagaan  Suvarga;  (ii)  expansion  of  existing  mining 
operations at Naryn Suhayt and Ovoo Tolgoi and other locations; (iii) development of associated 
power  stations  and  transport  infrastructure;  and  (iv)  strengthening  of  trade  corridors  with  the 
People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  through  the  border  town  at  Zamyn-Uud  in  Dornogovi,  and 
through  crossing  points  of  Gashuun  Suhayt  and  Shivee  Huren  in  Omnogovi,  and  Hangi  in 
Dornogovi.  
 
3. 
The  influx  associated  with  these  economic  activities  is  projected  to  more  than  double 
urban  populations  in  the  project  towns  by  2020.  For  some  soum1 centers  in  Southeast  Gobi 
(notably Hanbogd and Tsogttsetsii), population is expected to increase about tenfold by 2020. 
The  population  of  Zamyn-Uud,  currently  at  about  10,000,  is  expected  to  more  than  double  by 
2020. 
 
4. 
Effective  urban  infrastructure  and  services  are  prerequisites  for  sustainable  economic 
growth. In the urban areas of Southeast Gobi, many services are either inadequate or absent. 
The population has low levels of access to water supply and sanitation, and the smaller urban 
areas  do  not  have  piped  networks.  Reticulated  water  supply  networks  and  sewerage  systems 
serve  only  the  formal  areas  of  the  aimag  centers  and  Zamyn-Uud  soum;  the  majority  of  the 
population in these towns lives in ger (traditional felt tent) areas and do not benefit from network 
services (except through water kiosks). In other soum centers, water is only available from well 
points, and there are no sewerage systems. 
 
5. 
Strengthening the provision of basic urban services will require institutions and policies 
that provide incentives for performance while also ensuring affordability. Services are currently 
provided by utilities that are largely owned by local government, and are delivered at a loss due 
to  unwillingness  of  local  government  councils  to  raise  tariffs  to  cost-recovery  levels.  This  is 
costly in terms of resources spent on untargeted subsidies and foregone opportunities to attract 
private sector expertise and financing. The government is developing legislation that will enable 
efficient  delivery  of  municipal  services,  introducing  accountability  and  independent  regulation. 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has provided technical assistance for preparing legislation 
on public–private partnerships (PPPs). The proposed project will support these reforms. 
 
Less than 30% of the urban population has adequate water service, and only 17% has 
6. 
access to adequate sanitation services. The daily household water consumption in ger areas is 
5–10 liters per capita per day (lpcd), much less than the minimum of 25 lpcd recommended by 

                                                 
1 A  soum  is  the  administrative  unit  immediately  below  an  aimag  (province).  Each  aimag  comprises  a  number  of 
soums, at the center of which is a soum center—comprising several administrative buildings and a small population.  

 the  World  Health  Organization.  There  are  high  levels  of  unaccounted-for  water  from  the 
networks (about 40% of water produced).  
 
7. 
Economic developments are set to take place in a sparsely populated and largely poor 
area.  The  aimags  of  Dornogovi  and  Omnogovi  are  located  within  the  central  region,  which 
contains significant numbers of poor households. In Omnogovi, where disaggregated data are 
available, the percentage of households living below the poverty line in Dalanzadgad is 21%–
26%,  in  Hanbogd  soum  it  is  estimated  at  15%–25%,  and  in  Tsogttsetsii  soum  it  is  13%–26%. 
Households headed by women are more likely to be poor, and form a significant proportion of 
the total households living below the poverty line in Southeast Gobi.  
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

8. 
Rapid population growth. Southeast Gobi is set to experience rapid growth in its urban 
population. In Omnogovi, the mining sector could require up to 7,000 new employees by 2015 
and  an  additional  10,000  by  2020.  Many  mine  workers  and  their  families,  small  business 
owners, and others attracted to this high-growth area will locate outside mine fences in existing 
urban settlements. The major mining companies support a mixed model of operations whereby 
some  employees  are  transported  in  and  out  of  the  mine  site  from  afar,  while  others  live  in 
nearby settlements. The population at the three border-crossing points of Gashuun Suhayt and 
Shivee Huren in Omnogovi, and Hangi in Dornogovi is expected to grow quickly. In Dornogovi, 
the  cross-border  trade  with  the  PRC  at  the  Zamyn-Uud–Erlian  rail  crossing  point  has  been 
increasing  at  a  rate  of  26%  per  year  in  recent  years.  The  completion  of  the  Ulaanbaatar  to 
Zamyn-Uud road link and planned investments in logistics facilities at Zamyn-Uud will serve to 
significantly increase cross-border trade and result in a population influx.  
 
9. 
Uncoordinated  framework  for  subregional  development.  Efforts  to  reach  a  clear 
policy and strategic framework for the future development of the urban sector in Southeast Gobi 
are  compromised  by  institutional  fragmentation  and  a  lack  of  consensus  across  government 
departments  and  other  stakeholders.  The  National  Development  and  Innovation  Committee 
(NDIC)  and  the  Ministry  of  Road,  Transportation,  Construction  and  Urban  Development 
(MRTCUD) are carrying out work on aspects of the subregional strategy. The MRTCUD is in the 
process  of  finalizing  a  development  plan  for  the  Gobi  region  covering  Omnogovi,  Dornogovi, 
and  Dundgovi  aimags,  while  simultaneously  undergoing  reorganization  in  an  attempt  to  better 
align  its  functions  to  the  requirements  of  the  sector.  The  prioritization  and  sequencing  of 
investment  remains  unclear,  and  many  proposals  under  consideration  have  not  identified  any 
immediate  or  future  source  of  funding.  The  government  expects  to  establish  a  regional 
development council to coordinate investments in Omnogovi and possibly other aimags. 
 
10. 
Poor  urban  planning.  Translating  economic  activity  and  population  growth  into  real 
benefits for residents of Southeast Gobi will depend on the development of livable urban places. 
This, in turn, requires effective urban planning and a framework for the provision of high-quality 
municipal  services.  The  project  will  address  these  needs  by  supporting  priority  investments, 
institutional  reform,  and  capacity  development.  The  aimag  and  soum  centers  are  poorly 
equipped  to  deal  with  the  impact  that  rapid  growth  from  mining  and  trade  will  have  on  their 
planning systems, infrastructure, and services. Although master plans have been prepared for 
some of the project towns, these are based on past natural population growth trends and do not 
accommodate  the  populations  now  anticipated  as  a  result  of  the  projected  influx.  It  is  unclear 
how  proposed  investments  will  be  financed,  and  the  institutional  strengthening,  capacity 
building, and reform needed to ensure that the plans are effectively executed and services are 
well managed have not been addressed. 

2 

 

 

  
The rapid allocation of land for khashaas (land plots) based on the Law on the Allocation 
11. 
of  Land  to  Mongolian  Citizens  has  resulted  in  land  being  allocated  in  a  way  that  bears  little 
relation to the provisions of town master plans.2 Demands for land for housing and commercial 
uses  are  increasing  rapidly  and  are  overwhelming  the  capacity  of  local  governments  to  deal 
effectively with them, resulting in poorly planned development and adding to the eventual costs 
of  servicing  developments.  Competing  and  conflicting  land  uses  and  the  limited  amount  of 
developable land in Zamyn-Uud is already resulting in major development challenges, which will 
be repeated in the other high-growth towns unless better tools and systems are put in place.  
 
12. 
Constrained  local  resources. The aimag governments of Southeast Gobi, in common 
with those elsewhere in the country, lack fiscal autonomy. In a system set out in the 2003 Public 
Sector Management and Finance Law, aimag government revenues comprise taxes decided by 
the  assemblies,  shared  taxes,  and  nontax  revenues.  Aimag  governments  have  few  revenue-
raising powers; local taxes, corporate income tax, and excises, which were shared before 2003, 
are  now  retained  by  the  central  government.  Value-added  tax  is  shared,  but  the  proportion  is 
decided annually by the central government. All taxes are collected by the General Department 
for  National  Taxation  and  then  transferred  to  subnational  governments.  Local  governments 
require  regular  and  predictable  income  to  cover  establishment  and  operational  costs  and  to 
provide funding for local development. A more formalized allocation process that is transparent, 
sustainable, and predictable is required.  
 
13. 
Struggling service institutions. Aimag-owned urban services companies, called public 
urban service organizations (PUSOs),3 have difficulty maintaining existing levels of service and 
are  not  in  a  position  to  expand  service  coverage  to  meet  expected  demand  for  services  and 
infrastructure. They are guided in part by management contracts with the aimag, which describe 
general responsibilities but lack specificity on service quality and coverage, dispute resolution, 
and remuneration. Soum governments have departments (mini-PUSOs) that are responsible for 
small-scale  heating  and  water  operations.  The  PUSOs  and  mini-PUSOs  struggle  to  recover 
operating  and  maintenance  costs  and  lack  access  to  training  and  managerial  expertise.  The 
most  fundamental  constraint  is  low  tariffs;  PUSO  requests  for  increases  to  enable  routine 
operating  and  maintenance  costs  to  be  recovered  are  often  rejected  by  the  aimag  Citizens' 
Representatives  Khural 4  due  to  the  political  unpopularity  of  such  adjustments. 5  Under  the 
proposed  project  there  is  an  opportunity  to  introduce  a  new  arrangement  for  tariff  formulation, 
whereby  they  are  set  through  competitively  awarded  contracts  with  the  private  sector  and 
regulated by a central independent body.  
  
14. 
Operational  performance  of  institutions  responsible  for  delivering  urban  services  varies 
but  is  generally  characterized  by  low  levels  of  access, inefficiency,  and  deficiencies  in  quality. 
For example, less than one-third of the population in the project towns has access to household 
water supply and district heating. The daily household water consumption in ger areas is 5–10 
lpcd,  much  less  than  the  25  lpcd  minimum  recommended  by  the  World  Health  Organization. 
Water losses are very high, estimated at 20%–40% of water produced, and energy losses from

3

 

 heating  systems  are  estimated  at  40%  or  more.  Although  water  quality  is  generally  good,  raw 
water  often  has  a  high  mineral  content.  There  are  also  reported  health  problems  due  to 
contamination  from  pit  latrines  or  leaking  sewerage  lines.  Sewage  is  often  left  untreated. 
Staffing  levels  in  the  PUSOs  are  much  higher  than  what  would  be  expected  at  an  efficiently 
managed water, heating, and sanitation utility. 
 
15. 
The project presents an opportunity to introduce fundamental changes to the institutional 
framework for municipal service  provision and its regulation. Recent technical assistance from 
ADB  has  yielded  recommendations,  developed  in  cooperation  with  SPC,  MRTCUD,  and  the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF), including (i) divesting all or part of PUSOs so as to decouple service 
providers  from  local  government  administration  and  attract  private  capital  and  expertise;  (ii) 
introducing  a  lease  contract  that  provides  performance-based  incentives  for  the  service 
provider; and (iii) establishing a regulatory mechanism at a central level, which links tariffs with 
the prices of key inputs, avoids political involvement in tariff setting, and reduces the regressive 
nature  of  the  current  tariff  structure  whereby  residents  of  formal  areas  pay  less  than  their 
neighbors in ger areas. These steps will be supported under the project, with a view to driving 
changes in other aimags over time. 
 
16. 
Inadequate infrastructure and service provision. The quality, coverage, and reliability 
of  urban  services  within  the  project  aimag  and  soum  centers  vary  widely.  Less  than  30%  of 
urban  households  within  the  aimags  have  access  to  household  water  supply  and  district 
heating. Still less have access to sanitary sewerage. The ger areas in the aimag centers and in 
Zamyn-Uud rely on water from water kiosks and on-plot sanitation, and the low levels of water 
consumption and poor sanitation increase the risk of waterborne and water-washed diseases. In 
the other soum centers, there are no piped water supply and wastewater systems; all residents 
rely on wells and pit latrines. 
 
17. 
Solid-waste  collection  management  and  disposal  systems  are  generally  nonexistent  or 
at  best  rudimentary  in  the  aimag  and  soum  centers.  It  is  estimated  that  less  than  50%  of  the 
population is served by a regular garbage collection system, including some handled by small 
private operators engaged by the soum governments. No secure sanitary landfills exist, and the 
solid waste collected is disposed of onto open sites. This causes pollution through the spreading 
of waste. Wind-blown plastic bags are becoming a feature of the Gobi Desert landscape.  
 
18. 
The absence of an extensive paved road network in the aimag centers and any paved 
roads  at  all  in  most  of  the  soum  centers  prevents  clear  definition  of  rights  of  way  and  major 
circulation  routes.  The  dust  which  is  generated  by  vehicles  riding  on  the  unpaved  dirt  roads 
contributes to air pollution and has a negative impact on quality of life. 
 
19. 
Underinvestment  in  infrastructure,  and  shortcomings  in  its  operation  and  maintenance, 
raises  costs  for  businesses  and  restricts  access  to  jobs  and  services.  There  are  significant 
disparities  in  the  level  of  services  provided  in  formal  planned  areas  in  these  towns  and  the 
adjacent  ger  areas.  The  urban  poor  suffer  disproportionately  from  inadequate  provision, 
management,  and  maintenance  of  urban  infrastructure.  They  are  exposed  to  risks  associated 
with  deficient  service  provision;  they  lack  adequate  means  to  avoid  the  effects  of  poor  water 
supply, 
the  most  severely 
disadvantaged  by  the  absence  of  suitable  roads.  The  poor  stand  to  benefit  significantly  from 
improved infrastructure and service provision.  
 
20. 
Poor  cross-border  cooperation.  The  potential  benefits  of  close  cross-border 
cooperation  are  compromised  by  the  lack  of  effective  cross-border  institutions  and  an 

insufficient  heating,  and  are 

inadequate  sanitation,  and 

4 

 

 

 associated  lack  of  investment  on  the  Mongolian  side.  Action  is  required  to  narrow  the  gaps  in 
trade  logistics  and  urban  infrastructure  development  as  well  as  in  the  associated  trade 
processes. The unevenness of development is contributing to delays which are to the detriment 
of growth in cross-border trade. As delays occur, higher trade-related transaction costs worsen 
the opportunity to handle increasing volumes of trade and there is less incentive for investment. 
 
21. 
Prior external assistance. Several development partners are active in the urban sector 
in Mongolia, notably the World Bank (integrated urban development, ger area development, and 
urban  air  quality),  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  (water  supply,  and  urban  planning 
and  transport  in  Ulaanbaatar),  and  German  development  cooperation  through  GTZ  (urban 
environment  and  energy  efficiency).  The  World  Bank  prepared  the  Southern  Mongolia 
Infrastructure Strategy6 in 2008–2009, which focused on infrastructure and institutional needs in 
Omnogovi  and  brought  stakeholders  together  to  discuss  these.  It  is  preparing  a  technical 
assistance  project  that  will  strengthen  groundwater  monitoring  and  support  development  of 
transactions  for  private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure.  Appendix  3  provides  more  details 
on development coordination in the sector.  
 
ADB  is  supporting  several  ongoing  and  planned  activities  in  Southeast  Gobi.  About 
22. 
$1.3 million  has  been  expended  on  rehabilitating  urban  services 
in  Saynshand  and 
Dalanzadgad.  More  than  $1  million  has  been  invested  in  Omnogovi  aimag  and  $0.5  million  in 
Dornogovi  aimag  for  rehabilitating  schools,  providing  textbooks  and  tool  kits,  and  training 
teachers;  and  $1.3  million  has  been  invested  in  Dornogovi  aimag  for  rehabilitating  and 
constructing  aimag  and  soum  hospitals,  capacity  building  and  training,  and  providing  medical 
equipment and motorbikes. In 2009, an advisory technical assistance project began supporting 
HIV/AIDS  prevention  in  ADB  infrastructure  projects  and  the  mining  sector.  An  ADB-financed 
project  preparatory  technical  assistance  project is  currently supporting  the  development  of  the 
Regional  Logistics  Development  Project  for  trade  logistics  facilities  at  Zamyn-Uud,  and 
supplementary  financing  for  the  Regional  Road  Development  Project  to  complete  the  road 
corridor between Zamyn-Uud and Choyr is expected to begin in April 2010. 
 
23. 
Lessons. Institutional weakness is a key constraint on timely and efficient execution of 
projects  and  on  long-term  sustainability  of  the  assets  created.  Local  capacity  constraints  are 
exacerbated  by  a  highly  centralized  system  of  government  in  which  local  infrastructure 
investments  remain  largely  at  the  discretion  of  the  central  government,  and  local  officials  lack 
the budgetary and human resources to properly maintain infrastructure and effectively respond 
to  constituents'  needs.  Incentives  and  resources  for  local  governments  to  strengthen  services 
are  limited.  The  proposed  project  addresses  the  opportunity  for  greater  local  involvement  in 
project  planning,  design,  and  implementation,  and  the  issue  of  capacity  constraints  and  poor 
incentives  for  quality  service  provision  at  the  local  level.  In  adopting  a  design-and-build 
procurement  modality,  the  project  eliminates  problems  experienced  in  prior  ADB  loans  where 
there is difficulty in assigning responsibility for deficiencies when infrastructure is turned over to 
local authorities.      
 
24. 
Projects  have  had  only  limited  and  variable  success  in  raising  tariffs,  resulting  in 
underfunding of operation and maintenance. The support of ADB and other donors has focused 
on rebuilding assets in a variety of urban subsectors, but has placed less emphasis on building 
the  institutions  and  systems  required  to  ensure  these  assets  are  maintained  and  operated 
efficiently.  Given  the  acute  needs  in  urban  areas  in  the  1990s,  the  emphasis  on  building  and 
rehabilitating  assets  was  justified.  Today,  it  is  clear  that  Mongolia  lags  behind  other  former

socialist  countries  in  institutional  reform  and  strengthening,  and  risks  wasting  resources  on 
infrastructure  that  is  not  well  maintained  and  managed.  Appendix  2  provides  more  details  on 
challenges and opportunities in the urban sector.  
 
Link to government and ADB strategies. The project will be included in the Mongolia 
25. 
country  partnership  strategy  and  has  been  prepared  based  on  (i)  the  National  Development 
Strategy  and  ADB-supported  urban  sector  road  map;  (ii)  the  World  Bank-supported  report  on 
the Southern Mongolia Infrastructure Strategy (and particularly sections on housing and urban 
infrastructure);  (iii)  the  government’s  draft  Infrastructure  Development  Plans  for  the  Southern 
Gobi  prepared  by  the  NDIC; 7 (iv)  planned  logistics  infrastructure  development  at  Zamyn-Uud 
and other border crossings; (v) the land management plan for the “Galbyn Gobi” micro-regional 
development  concept  prepared  under  the  guidance  of  the  MRTCUD;  (vi)  urban  development 
master  plans  and  investment  plans  prepared  for  aimag  centers  and  key  soum  centers  in  the 
region; and (vii) meetings and workshops with government officials, the private sector, and other 
stakeholders including town residents. 
 
An urban development road map for the region has been prepared, which sets out the 
26. 
development  goals  and  objectives  for  urban  development  for  2010  to  2015,  and  identifies 
investments  to  achieve  these  objectives.  Based  on  the  road  map,  an  institutional  reform  and 
development  framework  has  been  developed  which  will  support  effective  planning,  financing, 
and  operation  of  urban  infrastructure  and  services.  This  sets  out  specific  reforms,  associated 
capacity  development,  and  a  timetable  for  implementation.  Emphasis  is  placed  on  improving 
local governance and urban planning and management capacity, improving the institutional and 
contractual  arrangements  for  service  provision,  enhancing  national  and  local  urban  planning 
systems  and  capacities,  and  minimizing  recurrent  expenditures  and  establishing  clear 
accountability for the performance of contractors and service providers. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

27. 
The impact of the project will be enhanced economic development and livability in aimag 
centers  and  mining  and  border  towns  in  Southeast  Gobi.  The  outcome  of  the  project  will  be 
improved urban governance8 and expanded access to sustainable infrastructure and services in 
urban places in Southeast Gobi. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
B. 

Outputs 

To achieve these outcomes, the project will include two parts: institutional and capacity 

28. 
development, and priority infrastructure improvements. 
 
29. 
Part  A  will  finance  consulting  services  to  support  (i)  infrastructure  services  reforms 
including performance-based contracts for urban services delivery, (ii) institutional development 
and  capacity  building  to  strengthen  urban  planning  and  policy  making,  (iii)  strengthening  of 
regional  cooperation  for  urban  development,  and  (iv)  project  management  and  project 
performance monitoring.

with  drafting  and  tendering  operating  management  contracts,  capacity  development  for  the

Institutional  development  to  strengthen  urban  planning  and  policy  making  will  focus  on 
31. 
the  MRTCUD  and  the  two  aimag  centers,  with  the  soum  centers  linking  into  the  aimags  for 
planning  support.  Assistance  will  be  provided  in  developing  urban  master  plans  in  each 
participating town, which will take account of town-specific aspects including the development of 
an industrial park at Saynshand and a free economic zone at Zamyn-Uud. Support at the aimag 
level will help aimag and soum governments manage their urban development functions more 
effectively.  More  details  on  support  for  project  management,  organizational  development  and 
capacity building are in Appendix 5. 
 
32. 
Part  A  of  the  project  will  also  support  the  creation  of  cross-border  institutions  with 
neighboring  districts  of  the  PRC  to  improve  the  efficiency  of  border  trade  and  exploit 
opportunities  for  shared  utilization  of  assets. 10  A  joint  border  commission  will  be  created 
comprising  local  government  and  business  representatives  from  Mongolia  and  the  PRC.  The 
commission  will  form  separate  working  groups  to  resolve  urban  and  border  trade  processing 
issues.  The  processing  working  group  will  address  processing  issues  leading  to  greater 
efficiency  in  cross-border  transactions.  An  urban  working  group  will  review  and  resolve  urban 
infrastructure,  operational,  environmental,  and  institutional  issues,  thereby  contributing  to 
reduced disparity in the development of towns on the Mongolian and PRC sides of the border. 
 
33. 
Project  management  and  implementation  support  under  part  A  will  ensure  that  project 
investments  are  designed  and  constructed  as  planned  and  that  resources  are  developed  to 
provide  for  sustainable  management  of  the  infrastructure  so  created.  It  will  also  support  the 
development and implementation of a project benefit monitoring and evaluation system that will 
enable early identification of implementation problems and measurement of the project’s impact.  
 
34. 
Part  B  will  finance  priority  infrastructure  improvements  providing  (i)  water  source 
development,  transmission,  storage,  and  distribution,  allowing  increased  connections  to  piped 
water  supply  and  reducing  system  leakage;  (ii)  increased  wastewater  collection  coverage  and 
enhanced  capacity  for  wastewater  treatment  and  effluent  reuse;  (iii)  improved  efficiency  and 
coverage  of  district  heating  services;  (iv)  surfaced  central  road  networks;  (v)  development  of 
controlled solid-waste landfills and enhanced capacity for solid-waste collection; and (vi) in one

35. 
In the water supply sector the project will support high-priority infrastructure investments 
to  upgrade  existing  bore  wells  and  provide  trunk  transmission,  distribution,  and  water 
distribution  points  (water  kiosks)  for  ger  areas.  In  the  three  larger  towns,  the  project  will 
augment  the  existing  water  supply  systems.  In  the  three  small  towns,  wholly  new  piped  water 
supply  systems  will  be  constructed.  Offsite  provision  in  all  three  small  soums  will  be  supplied 
from the adjacent mining companies which plan to deliver water to reservoir tanks outside the 
towns.  Service  levels  will  include  in-house  connections  where  possible.  Apartment  blocks, 
houses, and all nonresidential buildings will have multifaucet piped water supplies. Where this is 
not possible or affordable, such as in the ger areas,11 the aim is to have water kiosks within 300 
meters  of  any  town  dweller.  In  the  case  of  rehabilitated  and  new  production,  the  project  will 
ensure  effective  coordination  and  consultation  with  the  National  Water  Authority,  which 
oversees  water  resource  management  issues,  and  with  any  future  groundwater  monitoring 
agencies.  
 
36. 
In the wastewater sector, the project will rehabilitate and expand the existing sewerage 
systems in the three larger towns and provide new sewerage systems in the small towns. These 
sewerage  systems  will  link  unsewered  permanent  housing  areas  to  the  sewerage  system. 
Wastewater  treatment  in  all  cases  will  use  waste  stabilization  ponds  which  are  simple  to 
construct  and  manage  and  have  only  modest  power  requirements.  In  Gurvantes  there  is  a 
problem with run-off from the hills and an interceptor drain is included under part B to protect the 
town from storm flash flooding. In district heating, the project will adopt a similar approach with 
augmentation and some rehabilitation of existing systems in the larger towns and new systems 
in  most  of  the  smaller  soum  centers.  The  project  will  provide  new  boilers,  pumps,  and  boiler

8 

 

 

 

 houses  in  some  cases,  combined  with  the  replacement  of  inefficient  pipes  and  exchangers  to 
produce more efficient heating systems.   
 
37. 
Road  improvements  are  proposed  for  the  two  aimag  centers  and  in  Gurvantes, 
Hanbogd,  and  Tsogttsetsii  soums  to  provide  better  form  and  structure  to  the  towns.  This  will 
assist in guiding growth, and reduce dust from driving on existing dirt roads. By defining driving 
space, roads accidents will also be reduced. Since the cost of asphalt roads in this area would 
be  similar  to  the  cost  of  concrete  roads,  and  as  concrete  roads  last  longer  and  require  less 
maintenance, it is proposed to use concrete for all roads.   
 
38. 
The  approach  to  solid-waste  management  will  support  the  ongoing  initiatives  recently 
commenced by most local governments. The project aims to ensure that all waste is collected 
and transported to sites where it can be recycled or disposed of to sanitary landfill sites. This will 
entail  capping  existing  dumpsites,  developing  new  landfill  sites,  and  providing  collection  and 
landfill equipment. 
 
C. 

Special Features 

39. 
Implementation  arrangements  for  the  project  provide  aimag  governments  with  a 
substantive  role  in  implementation.  Lessons  from  three  ADB-financed  urban  infrastructure 
projects  in  Mongolia  indicate  that  deficiencies  in  design  quality  and  delays  in  implementation 
could be avoided if local governments were involved in design and supervision of infrastructure 
investments.  This  is  also  supported  by  international  experience,  which  suggests  that  the 
responsibilities  of  local  government  should  be  aligned  with  its  accountability  for  the  quality  of 
service  provision.  For  this  reason,  aimag  governments  will  be  the  contracting  authority  for 
design-and-build contracts under part B, and will benefit from technical assistance under part A. 
  
40. 
Another special feature of the project will be opportunities for private sector participation 
in providing and managing urban services. During project implementation, a service provider will 
be  engaged  in  each  of  the  two  project  aimags  under  a  lease  arrangement  (operating 
management  contract  [OMC])  to  operate,  maintain,  expand,  and  improve  urban  services  in 
project aimag and soum centers for 10–15 years.  
 
41. 
Two  parallel  sets  of  project  activities  will  contribute  to  this  objective.  First,  aimag 
governments  will  tender  the  package  of  priority  infrastructure  improvements  under  a  design-
and-build  modality.  Under  advance  action,  consultants  will  be  recruited  to  prepare  reference 
designs and contract documents for three contracts (two in Omnogovi and one in Dornogovi) for 
the  design  and  construction  of  the  priority  infrastructure  improvements  in  aimag  and  soum 
centers.  The  aimag  governments  will  be  supported  by  project  implementation  unit  (PIU) 
consultants  and  PUSO  staff  who  will  be  seconded  part-time  to  the  project  to  assist  in 
supervision.  
 
42. 
Second, under part A and in parallel with preparing and tendering each design-and-build 
contract,  consultants  will  advise  government  on  structuring  long-term  OMCs  between  each 
aimag government and a private sector urban services company (USC) for operation of existing 
and new assets. The OMC would cover the  aimag centers and soum centers for each aimag, 
and be regulated through the terms of the contract. A central independent regulatory body, to be 
established  with  assistance  under  the  project,  will  set  service  quality  standards  and  minimum 
tariffs. The USC, upon being awarded the OMC, will gain an equity stake in the PUSO and its 
operating  assets;  the  balance  of  the  PUSO’s  shares  will  be  owned  by  the  aimag  government

and PUSO managers and staff. The OMC will be awarded for a minimum of 10 years. Details of 
the contracts will be determined on the basis of transaction advice to be provided under part A.

F. 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Project Management 

The  MRTCUD  will  be  the  executing  agency,  supported  by  a  project  management  unit 
46. 
(PMU)  headed  by  a  project  director.  The  MRTCUD  will  be  responsible  for  overall  strategic 
guidance,  technical  supervision,  and  execution  of  the  project,  ensuring  compliance  with  grant 
covenants. Implementation of the priority infrastructure investments component (part B) will be 
carried  out  by  the  aimag  governments.  PIUs  will  be  established  in  each  aimag  and  will  be 
responsible for day-to-day implementation of physical works. The MRTCUD will coordinate the 
activities of the two PIUs at the aimag level through consultants and PMU staff, and will facilitate 
processing  and  approvals  of  designs,  contracts,  and  other  documents  as  required  at  the 
ministry level. The project director, supported by the PMU and consultants, will (i) coordinate all 
activities  under  the  project;  (ii)  be  responsible  for  overall  project  execution,  monitoring,  and 
supervision; and (iii) will directly report to the chair of the project steering committee (PSC).  
 
A state-level PSC will be set up with full powers to take decisions on matters relating to 
47. 
project execution. The project director will be the member secretary and the committee will be 
chaired by the state secretary of the MRTCUD. Members of the committee will include the chair 
of the NDIC, director of the Budget Policy Department of the MOF, and representatives of the 
Ministry  of  Nature,  Environment  and  Tourism,  Ministry  of  Mineral  Resources  and  Energy, 
MRTCUD, and the aimag governments of Dornogovi and Omnogovi. Once the project is made 
effective,  the  PSC  will  meet  at  quarterly  intervals  to  review  project  performance  and  take 
decisions  on  major  issues  such  as  counterpart  funding,  implementation  bottlenecks,  land 
disputes,  special  procurement,  and  policy  reforms.  More  details  on  project  execution  and 
implementation arrangements are in Appendix 7. 
 
48. 
The PMU will be responsible for (i) appointing project management, detailed design, and 
construction supervision consultants; (ii) approving the design of the investment components in 
consultation with the aimag governments and  project towns; (iii) assisting the PIUs to prepare 
standard  bid  documents,  monitoring  the  tendering  process,  and  guiding  the  project  towns  in 
evaluating bids and preparing bid evaluation reports for approval by ADB; (iv) coordinating with 
ADB on matters related to disbursement; (v) monitoring compliance with grant covenants; and 
(vi) maintaining project documents and submitting timely reports to ADB. 
 
49. 
The  MRTCUD  will  be  the  implementing  agency  for  part  A.  The  participating  aimag 
governments  will  be  the  implementing  agencies  for  part  B.  In  each  aimag,  a  PIU  will  be 
established and headed by a senior technical staff member experienced in water supply, public 
health,  and  environmental  engineering.  The  PIUs  will  comprise  three  sections:  (i)  urban 
infrastructure  and  services,  (ii)  community  awareness  and  participation,  and  (iii)  finance  and 
administration.  The  responsibilities  of  the  PIUs  shall  include  (i)  carrying  out  detailed  surveys, 
investigations,  and  engineering  designs  of  the  subprojects;  (ii)  with  the  assistance  of 
consultants,  preparing  bid  documents,  tendering,  evaluating  bids,  and  awarding  works;  (iii) 

 

11

 

 contract  administration,  supervision  and  quality  control,  measuring  works  carried  out  by 
contractors,  and  certifying  payments;  (iv)  conducting  public  awareness  campaigns  and 
participation  programs;  (v)  benefit  monitoring  and  evaluation  studies  and  environmental 
assessment;  (vi)  implementing  resettlement  plans;  and  (vii)  preparing  monthly  reports.  Aimag 
governments will implement the subprojects with technical assistance from the PIUs.  
 
50. 
The  performance  of  each  PIU  will  be  monitored  and  guided  by  aimag  working  groups 
chaired  by  the  aimag  governors.  The  working  groups  will  comprise  representatives  from  the 
aimag government, soum governors, PIU, PUSO, participating community-based organizations, 
and  civil  society  representatives  to  include  prominent  citizens.  The  aimag  working  group  will 
meet at least once every 6 months to review the progress and resolve local issues and policy 
matters.

contracts  with  a  value  less  than  $500,000  will  follow  national  competitive  bidding  (NCB),  and

procedures will be documented in the procurement plan. Any internationally tendered equipment 
packages  will  include  the  necessary  technical  support  to  ensure  proper  installation,  testing, 
commissioning,  and  training  of  operational  staff  as  part  of  the  related  contracts.  The

Advance Contracting and Retroactive Financing 

55. 
To  facilitate  timely  implementation,  the  government  has  requested  consideration  of 
advance  contracting  and  retroactive  financing  of  eligible  expenditures  up  to  20%  of  the 
proposed grant, incurred prior to effectiveness but not earlier than 12 months before the date of 
signing of the grant agreement. The issuance of invitations to bid or prequalify under advance 
contracting and retroactive financing would be subject to ADB approval. All advance contracting 
and retroactive financing would be undertaken according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines and 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  The  government  acknowledges  that  any  approval  of

6. 

Anticorruption Policy and Government Measures  

56. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  MRTCUD  and  aimag  governments.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good 
governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or 
through its agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the 
project. To support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included 
in  the  grant  regulations  and  the  bidding  documents  for  the  project.  In  particular,  all  contracts 
financed  by  ADB  in  connection  with  the  project  will  include  provisions  specifying  the  right  of 
ADB to audit and examine the records and accounts of the MRTCUD, the aimag governments, 
and  all  contractors,  suppliers,  consultants,  and  other  service  providers  as  they  relate  to  the 
project.  The  MRTCUD  and  the  aimag  governments  will  undertake  the  following  actions  as 
specified in the anticorruption strategy (Supplementary Appendix Z): (i) introduce a dual-signing 
system in which the civil works contractor agrees to an anticorruption clause in the contract with 
the  employer;  (ii)  adopt  third-party  oversight  (under  the  PMU)  involving  periodic  inspection  of 
contractors' activities related to construction, fund withdrawals, and settlements; (iii) community 
oversight over the works, implemented in partnership with local nongovernment organizations; 
and (iv) extensive public disclosure of key contract documents. Tender, construction, financial, 
and summary technical information will be disclosed on the project website, in local government 
offices,  and  on  notice  boards  at  the  project  site.  At  any  time  during  implementation  and 
afterwards,  project  management  or  community  members  who  suspect  corruption  or  have 
grievances  will  be  able  to  contact  the  PMU  through  the  PIU  or  aimag  government,  who  are 
obligated  to  convey  such  information  unchanged  and  without  delay  to  the  PMU  and  the 
executing  agency. All  complaints  will  be  assessed,  instances  of  suspected  corruption  will  be 
investigated,  and  sanctions  will  be  imposed  on  those  against  whom  corrupt  practices  are 
proved.

7. 

Disbursement Arrangements 

57. 
The  grant  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook 
(2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  To  expedite  project  implementation  through  timely 
release of grant proceeds, the PMU will establish and administer two imprest accounts—one for 
component  A,  and  one  for  component  B—promptly  after  grant  effectiveness  at  a  commercial 
bank acceptable to ADB.13 A sub-account will be established and administered by each of the 
two  PIUs. 14  Replenishment  of  the  sub-accounts  will  be  based  on  quarterly  plans  for 
management and operations expenses and submission of full supporting documentation to the 
PMU. Disbursements from the imprest accounts will be supported by an appropriate withdrawal 
application  and  related  documentation.  Such  documentation  will  demonstrate,  among  other 
things,  that  the  goods  and/or  services  are  procured  from  ADB’s  member  countries,  and  are 
eligible for ADB financing. The maximum amount to be deposited into each imprest account will 
not exceed the estimated expenditures to be financed from the respective imprest account for 
the  next  6 months,  or  10%  (in  aggregate)  of  the  grant  amount,  whichever  is  lower.  ADB’s 
statement of expenditures procedure may be used to reimburse, liquidate, or replenish eligible 
expenditures up to a ceiling of $100,000 per payment. Flow of funds under the grant is further 
described in Appendix 11. 
 

8. 

Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 

58. 
The government, through the PMU and PIUs, will maintain separate financial accounts 
for  the  project,  and  have  such  accounts  and  related  financial  statements  audited  annually  by 
independent  auditors  acceptable  to  ADB  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  the  grant 
agreement and as specified in ADB’s Financial Reporting and Auditing of Projects Financed by 
the  Bank. 15  The  auditors  should  have  qualifications,  experience,  and  terms  of  reference 
acceptable to ADB. The use of the imprest accounts and statement of expenditures will also be 
part  of  the  annual  audit  and  a  separate  audit  opinion  will  be  submitted.  The  government  will 
submit to ADB certified copies (in English) of such audited accounts and financial statements, 
and the related reports and auditors, within 6 months after the close of each fiscal year. 
 
59. 
For  the  purpose  of  complying  with  the  requirements  for  the  annual  audited  financial 
statements, the proceeds of this grant may be used to finance expenditures for private financial 
statements,  sector  auditors,  and  translations  of  auditor’s  reports  into  English.  The  PMU  will 
submit consolidated quarterly progress reports to ADB (in English) and to the government on all 
aspects  of  project  implementation.  The  reports  will  include  details  on  overall  implementation 
progress, problems encountered during the reporting period, measures taken or proposed to be 
taken  to  remedy  these  problems,  and  the  proposed  program  of  activities  for  the  following 
quarter.  Within  6 months  of  project completion, the  PMU  will  prepare  and  submit  to ADB,  in  a 
format acceptable to ADB, a project completion report on the utilization and impact of the grant; 
performance  of  the  project;  economic  and  social  benefits  generated;  and  details  about 
implementation, costs, resettlement, and other information requested by ADB.

Project Review 

63.

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

Benefits and Impacts 

A.  
 
64. 
Economic and financial benefits. The project will directly benefit about 100,000 people 
in six towns in Omnogovi and Dornogovi aimags, of whom approximately 30.7% live below the 
poverty  line.  The  project  components  have  strong  economic  rationale  since  they  provide 
minimum  acceptable  standards  for  basic  living  conditions  and  assist  in  removing  existing 
constraints  on  social  development  and  economic  growth.  Similarly,  priority  infrastructure 
improvements were designed in accordance with sound principles of priority need, consultation 
and  targeting,  and  demand  management.  The  project  supports  rehabilitation  before  new 
investment, and subprojects represent technically feasible options at least cost. The project will 
develop several direct and indirect benefits. Better access to potable water with improved water 
supply  and  sanitation  services  (in  formal  areas)  will  provide  several  long-  and  short-term 
benefits.  There  will  be  qualitative  improvement  in  the  lives  of  the  communities,  in  particular 
those people living in the ger areas. Living conditions will improve at individual and communal 
levels, including benefits from reduced water collection times and improved health. 

 

15

 

  
65. 
The water supply and wastewater economic analysis shows that economic internal rates 
of return are all well above the economic opportunity cost of capital of 12% in Mongolia, except 
in the case of Zamyn-Uud where it is marginally lower at 11.6% (Supplementary Appendix S). 
The  wide  range  (52.1%  in  Dalanzadgad  to  11.6%  in  Zamyn-Uud)  mainly  reflects  variations  in 
per  capita  costs  arising  out  of  the  base  population  and  the  characteristics  of  the  area.  The 
economic  internal  rates  of  return  when  subjected  to  sensitivity  tests  under  key  variables  are 
most  sensitive  to  decrease  in  benefits  associated  with  improved  infrastructure,  and  remain 
above the opportunity cost of capital in all towns except Zamyn-Uud. 
 
66. 
Financial  analysis  was  undertaken  for  revenue-generating  components,  including  a 
combined  analysis  of  water  supply  and  wastewater,  heating,  and  solid-waste  management. 
Basic  assumptions  in  computing  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  were  as  follows: 
(i) all revenues and costs are expressed in constant prices on an incremental basis; (ii) capital 
expenditures  include  all  costs,  less  taxes  and  duties  and  price  contingencies;  (iii)  capital 
expenditures are recorded at the time they are incurred, while interest and finance charges are 
excluded;  and  (iv)  incremental  operating  costs  are  calculated  by  subtracting  the  existing 
system’s  operating  costs  from  the  projected  operating  costs  for  the  whole  system  at  project 
completion.  The  value  of  benefits  arising  from  water  sales  was  calculated  by  multiplying  the 
volume  of  water  sold each  year  by  the  proposed  tariffs  used  for  each  year  in  constant  prices, 
with  an  annual  increase  of  6%  to  fall  in  line  with  inflation.  For  sewerage,  the  estimated  cash 
flows  were  based  on  the  wastewater  surcharge  on  water  bills.  Benefits  and  costs  were  kept 
constant after financial year 2021 when all facilities would be operating at near full capacity and 
present design demands would be fully satisfied. 
 
67. 
Financial  analysis  assumes  that  (i)  the  mini-PUSOs  at  the  soum  centers  will  be 
absorbed into the new USCs or fully established under the State and Local Property Law by the 
completion  of  the  project  by  2014  to  take  responsibility  for  owning  (or  leasing)  and  operating 
existing  and  proposed  services  under  the  project;  and  (ii)  the  services  which  are  currently 
provided  by  the  railways  in  Saynshand  and  Zamyn-Uud  will  be  transferred  to  the  existing 
PUSOs (or subsequent USC) in Saynshand and the fully fledged PUSO in Zamyn-Uud, or the 
new Omnogovi USC when established.  
 
68. 
The  combined  FIRRs  for  all  project  components  vary  between  23.7%  in  Dalanzadgad 
and  7.4%  in  Zamyn-Uud.  Combined  FIRRs  for  water  supply  and  wastewater  vary  between 
25.2%  in  Dalanzadgad  and  4.7%  in  Saynshand  (Supplementary  Appendix  T).  The  wide 
variation is mainly due to the nature of the scheme, distance from source, service coverage, and 
operation and maintenance costs. Piped water supply and wastewater in the smaller towns of 
Tsogttsetsii,  Hanbogd,  and  Gurvantes,  and  also  in  Zamyn-Uud,  are  new  and  therefore  cost-
intensive  with  full  benefits  to  be  derived  over  the  longer  term.  The  FIRRs  for  heating  services 
vary  between  24.9%  in  Hanbogd  and  18.9%  in  Gurvantes,  and  for  solid-waste  management 
between  25.6%  in  Zamyn-Uud  and  6.4%  Gurvantes.  Sensitivity  tests  indicate  that  FIRRs  are 
sensitive to decreased revenues and delays in project benefits by 1 year.

72. 
Gender  equality  impacts.  The  project  is  designed  to  produce  benefits  that  are 
disproportionately  directed  toward  women,  who  bear  most  of  the  burden  associated  with  poor 
service  delivery.  Women  and  their  children  spend  most  of  their  time  at  home  and  in  the 
neighborhood.  The  proposed  project  will  provide  opportunities  to  (i)  relieve  time  and  labor 
burdens  on  women  created  by  the  lack  of  access  to  basic  infrastructure  and  services; 
(ii) improve women’s living conditions, health, and hygiene; (iii) create employment and income-
generating  opportunities  for  women;  and  (iv)  empower  women  as  decision  makers  through 
active involvement of women in the development process. Activities, targets, and indicators are 
set out in a gender action plan in Appendix 9.

74. 
Environmental  impacts  and  benefits.  The  project  is  classified  as  environmental 
category  B.  Initial  environmental  examinations  (IEEs)  were  carried  out  for  all  of  the  part  B 
activities  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  In  accordance  with  ADB's 
information  and  disclosure  and  consultation  requirements,  these  subprojects  and  the  potential 
environmental impacts were presented and discussed at stakeholder meetings and focus group 
discussions.  Key  environmental  impacts  during  construction  are  largely  temporary  in  nature, 
and  include  dust,  gaseous  emissions,  noise,  and  some  public  inconvenience.  Operational 
impacts  might  include  gaseous  emissions,  contamination  of  water  supply,  improper  treatment 
and disposal of sludge, or escape of leachate. The extent of these impacts will be mitigated with 
measures  identified  in  the  IEEs  including  careful  project  management  and  contractor 
compliance during construction with an environmental management plan integral to the contract 
documents.  Key  mitigation  measures  during  operation  are  securing  an  adequate  operational 
budget,  implementing  reforms  to  service  institutions  under  the  project,  and  developing  (under 
the  project)  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  manuals  for  (i)  water  supply  and  wastewater 
management;  (ii)  solid  waste  management;  and  (iii)  district  heating  that  incorporate  the 
conditions  stipulated  in  the  environmental  permit,  if  necessary,  and  the  proposed  mitigation 
measures specified in the environmental management plan (EMP).  
 
75. 
The  recipient's  institutional  capacity  to  manage  environmental  risks  is  limited,  with  a 
single  trained  full-time  environmental  staff  member  working  at  the  aimag  level  and  a  single 
untrained environmental inspector covering all environmental matters in each soum. Aimag and 
soum  environmental  management  and  monitoring  capacity  will  be  strengthened  with  capacity 
development and training under part A, and the PIUs will be staffed and assisted with technical 
specialists  and  qualified  consultants  including  environmental  management  specialists.  The 
project  will  greatly  improve  community  health  and  living  conditions,  reduce  environmental 
pollution, and decrease per capita demand for energy resources by improving the efficiency of 
urban  services.  Priority  infrastructure  investments  in  solid-waste  management  will  reduce 
groundwater  pollution,  and  improved  urban  roads  will  reduce  dust  and  noise.  EMPs,  including 
the  Grievance  Redress  Mechanism  (GRM),  will  be  refined  during  the  detailed  design  stage 
using a consultation process with affected persons and closely consulting project stakeholders. 
An  environmental  safeguard  specialist  will  ensure  revised  IEEs  and  EMPs  during  detailed 
engineering design. 
 
76. 
Institutional  benefits.  There  is  a  need  for  reform,  organizational  development,  and 
institutional strengthening at the national and local government levels. Reform will focus on (i) 
service  delivery  with  the  development  of  enhanced  contractual  arrangements,  service  quality 
and  tariff  regulation,  and  partial  divestiture  of  utility  companies;  and  (ii)  urban  and  regional 
planning.  At  the  local  government  level,  institutional  development  and  capacity  building  will 
focus  on  planning  and  financial  management,  operation  and  maintenance  of  basic  urban 
infrastructure  and  facilities,  maintenance  planning  for  urban  services,  community  participatory 
structures and process, environmental monitoring, and handling of resettlement issues.  
 
B. 
 
77. 
The 2008 joint country portfolio performance review and a 2008 risk assessment for the 
education and urban infrastructure sectors noted key sector risks as poor capital investment and 

Risks 

18 

 

 

 budget  planning,  underdeveloped  institutional  frameworks  and  poor  capacity,  a  lack  of 
monitoring  and  evaluation,  poor  procurement  integrity,  and  weak  national  contractors.  The 
project  addresses  these  risks  by  including  capacity  building  at  national  and  local  government 
levels  in  investment  planning,  building  the  capacity  of  local  service  institutions  with  increased 
private  sector  participation,  focusing  institutional  change  on  measuring  and  improving  service 
delivery  performance,  adopting  a  design-and-build  modality  for  procurement  of  priority 
infrastructure improvements to attract better-qualified contractors, and combining individual civil 
works  activities  into  larger  contract  packages  to  generate  economies  of  scale  and  create 
packages which are eligible for ICB. The project will also introduce a dual-signing system and 
periodic inspections of contractors' activities as described in para. 59.  
 
78. 
It  is  assumed  that  anticipated  demand  for  urban  infrastructure  services  in  the  project 
towns  will  materialize.  The  influx  projections  underlying  the  selection  of  priority  infrastructure 
improvements  under  part  B  assume  that  mining  developments  continue  and  that  the  major 
mining  companies  remain  committed  to  forms  of  mine  development  that  support  urban 
development in neighboring towns, and complete power supply and water source development 
projects as planned. There is also an assumption that government policy continues to allow free 
movement of people to the project areas. 
 
79. 
Government policies on PPP for the provision of municipal services are central to project 
outcomes.  There  is  an  assumption  that  the  arrangements  for  the  proposed  reform  to  service 
delivery  institutions  in  aimag  and  soum  centers  is  supported,  in  particular  that  contracts  for 
operation of municipal services proceed and are supported by a viable independent regulatory 
mechanism.  Concrete  steps  have  been  taken  in  this  direction  and  are  backed  by  progress  on 
key  legislation  including  the  Law  on  Concessions.  There  is  an  assumption  that  the  domestic 
private sector is interested in partnering with the public sector to form USCs. Based on a market 
sounding  exercise  completed  in  2009,  there  are  strong  indications  of  interest  from  domestic 
firms.

The  government  has  given  the  following  assurances,  in  addition  to  the  standard

81. 
assurances, which will be incorporated in the legal documents. 
 
82.  Within  24  months  of  grant  effectiveness,  the  government  will  revise  the  Law  on 
Utilization of Water Supply and Sewerage Systems by Parliament, which includes, among other 
things, (i) establishment of an independent central regulator that will issue licenses and regulate 
tariffs  and  service  quality  levels;  and  (ii)  a  mechanism  by  which  contracted  private  operators 
may participate in operation of water and sewerage systems by contracting with central or local 

 

19

 

 authority,  as  the  case  may  be,  and  which  allows  such  contractors  to  set  tariff  or  service  fee, 
provided either the contract is consistent with the regulatory rules or the regulator approves the 
contract. 
 
83.  Within  24  months  of  grant  effectiveness,  each  participating  aimag  government  will 
execute  an  operating  management  contract  with  a  USC,  specifying:  minimum  tariffs,  and  how 
these  change  over  time;  minimum  service  quality  targets;  the  USC's  purchase  of  a  portion  of 
PUSO shares; the transfer of a portion of the PUSO's shares to PUSO management and staff; 
and the USC's investment in certain operating assets. In particular, each OMC will (i) allow that 
tariffs will be set at levels that recover at least O&M costs (including depreciation or renewals), 
and (ii) set service quality requirements so as to comply with relevant Mongolian law (including 
the  water  quality  guidelines  in  the  Water  Law,  2004  and  Law  on  Utilization  of  Water  and 
Sewerage  Services,  2002).  Such  tariffs  and  service  quality  requirements  may  differ  by  aimag 
and soum and between planned and ger areas.  
 
84. 
Prior to the period that OMCs will be operational, each aimag government will (i) ensure 
that  its  PUSO  will  operate  and  maintain  project  facilities  for  which  it  is  responsible;  and 
(ii) allocate and make available sufficient funds from its budget in a timely manner for each fiscal 
year for O&M of the project facilities.

Appendix 2 

URBAN SECTOR ANALYSIS  

 

1. 
The urban sector of Mongolia is small and is characterized by the primacy of Ulaanbaatar, and 
severe disparities in levels of urban service provision between the central formally planned (apartment) 
areas and peripheral unplanned (ger [traditional felt tent]) areas. The national urban population is about 
1.6 million, or 61% of the total population of 2.6 million, with 1.03 million (almost two-thirds of the urban 
total)  living  in  Ulaanbaatar.  Since  1990,  almost  all  urban  growth  has  been  absorbed  by  Ulaanbaatar, 
which  grew  at  2.6%  since  2004,  compared  to  less  than  1%  in  other  urban  centers.  With  sustained 
economic growth, urban poverty has been decreasing, with the reported incidence falling from 38% in 
2001  to  27%  in  2006,  although  poverty  incidence  in  aimag  (province)  and  soum  (district)  centers 
remains at about 37%.   

An  estimated  50%  of  the  urban  population  have  access  to  household  water  supplies  through 
2. 
centralized distribution networks in planned areas 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, whereas ger areas 
rely  largely  on  water  kiosks  served  through  the  distribution  network  or  by  tanker.  Here  water  usage 
averages 7–10 liters per capita per day, less than half the minimum recommended by the World Health 
Organization. Only central areas are sewered, with ger areas relying almost exclusively on unimproved 
open pit latrines or open field defecation. In the subsectors of solid-waste management, district heating, 
and  hot  water  supply,  a  similar  disparity  exists  between  adequate  service  in  planned  areas  and  no 
service  in  ger  areas.  In  addition,  ineffective  design  and  lack  of  maintenance  means  that  many  of  the 
piped networks within planned areas are in urgent need of rehabilitation. 

3. 
The  project  area  of  Southeast  Gobi  has  a  total  population  of  about  50,000,  but  is  set  to 
experience  rapid  growth  in  its  urban  population  as  a  result  of  the  influx  associated  with  trade  and 
mining investments. Efforts to reach a clear policy and strategic framework for the future development 
of  the  urban  sector  in  Southeast  Gobi  are  compromised  by  institutional  fragmentation  and  a  lack  of 
consensus  across  government  departments  and  other  stakeholders.  The  National  Development  and 
Innovation  Committee  (NDIC)  and  the  Ministry  of  Road,  Transportation,  Construction  and  Urban 
Development  (MRTCUD)  are  each  carrying  out  work  on  aspects  of  the  subregional  strategy.  The 
MRTCUD  is  in  the  process  of  finalizing  a  subregional  plan  for  the  Gobi  region  covering  Omnogovi, 
Dornogovi,  and  Dundgovi  aimags,  while  simultaneously  undergoing  reorganization  in  an  attempt  to 
better align its functions to the requirements of the sector. The MRTCUD needs to redefine its role as a 
facilitator and regulator of urban development rather than an implementer. The NDIC has prepared a 
strategy  for  the  development  of  infrastructure  (including  urban  infrastructure)  in  South  Gobi,  which  is 
awaiting cabinet approval. 

Major  sector  issues  include  (i)  a  distorted  and  poorly  functioning  urban  planning  system  and 
4. 
land  market;  (ii)  a  lack  of  rigor,  transparency,  and  accountability  in  urban  planning  and  investment 
decision  making;  (iii)  a deficiency  in  the  availability,  quality,  and  coverage  of  urban  infrastructure  and 
services,  especially  in  ger  areas;  (iv)  inadequate  cost  recovery  and  poor  financial  management  of 
public services; (v) lack of capacity of local governments to plan, and through the service organizations 
to provide and operate, urban infrastructure and facilities; (vi) inadequate focus on urban environmental 
problems,  particularly  in  Ulaanbaatar;  and  (xiii)  inadequate  attention  to,  and  allocation  of  sufficient 
resources for, maintenance of key infrastructure assets. 

5. 
In  the  project  aimags  of  Dornogovi  and  Omnogovi,  only  the  three  largest  settlements  of 
Dalanzadgad,  Saynshand,  and  Zamyn-Uud  have  formal  infrastructure  services  in  the  form  of  piped 
water supply, sewerage, and district heating networks. These are supplied only to formal housing areas 
and coverage is still limited as shown in Table A2.1. There is also a marked difference in the levels of 
service provided to formal housing areas and ger areas in these towns. Not only do the formal housing
