6. 
Apart from small district heating units that serve government offices and educational and health 
facilities, and a water supply system in Zuunbayan, all the other smaller soum settlements in Southeast 
Gobi  have  no  formal  network  infrastructure.  However,  as  all  water  is  groundwater,  all  town  dwellers 
purchase  water  supplied  by  government  from  bore  wells.  The  issue  is  that  some  urban  ger  dwellers 
have to travel more than 1 kilometer to collect water. 

7. 
A  major  constraint  on  providing  sufficient  levels  of  infrastructure  service  to  gers  is  the  low 
densities,  which  make  service  provision  expensive.  This  is  exacerbated  by  climatic  conditions  where 
the  very  cold  winter  months  preclude  even  the  provision  of  yard  standposts  for  water  supply  to  ger 
dwellers as the pipes would freeze unless insulated and heated during winter. Indoor connections are 
only viable for formal housing and are generally impractical in gers.  

8. 
As  there  is  no  perennial  surface  water  near  the  towns,  nearly  all  water  in  urban  areas  is 
purchased.  In  the  three  large  towns,  water  is  pumped  from  bore  wells  close  to  the  town,  treated  to 
reduce hardness, chlorinated, and pumped to reservoir tanks which serve the town with a continuous 
water supply service. In contrast, the kiosks that serve those living in ger areas are often only open for 
a few hours per day on certain days of the week.   

9. 
Most of the formal apartment areas in the three larger project towns have sewerage coverage. 
There  is  no  wastewater  system  in  the  three  smaller  project  towns  and  in  the  ger  areas  of  the  larger 
towns. Nearly all families living in these areas use outside dry pit latrines and, due to the lack of water 
connections, there are practically no water-sealed latrines in use. In the smaller towns, even institutions 
such as offices, hospitals, and school dormitories use unsanitary dry pit latrines. Not all of the formal 
housing  is  connected  to  sewers,  and  some  large  medium-density  housing  areas  still  use  outdoor  pit 
latrines.  All  three  of  the  large  towns  have  wastewater  treatment  plants  which  use  simple  waste 
stabilization pond technology. The effluent from all plants is disposed of to the desert, which does not 
cause  too  much  of  an  environmental  problem  as  there  is  no  habitation  around  these  ponds  and  the 
desert can readily absorb the relatively low flows.  

District  heating  is  provided  in  all  six  towns—in  the  three  larger  towns,  to  a  combination  of 
10. 
domestic users, government offices, and commercial properties; in the three smaller towns the district 
heating systems only supply government institutions and one or two commercial enterprises. In some 
of the large towns, limited hot water supply is also provided along with the heating system. All heating 
systems are based on old Russian-style systems with coal-fired boilers pumping heated water or steam 
to a high-pressure closed system. The heating is then taken to indoor radiators through separate lower-

 
 

 

 28 

Appendix 2 

 

pressure hot water systems heated by conduction in an exchanger from the high-pressure system. The 
boilers in most of the systems are outdated and have very low efficiency.  

11. 
In  Dornogovi,  both  Saynshand  and  Zamyn-Uud  are  connected  to  the  national  grid  through  a 
220 kilovolt-ampere  line,  which  runs  from  Choyr  to  Zamyn-Uud.  Zamyn-Uud  also  previously  imported 
power  from  the  People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC).  None  of  Omnogovi  aimag  is  connected  to  the 
national  grid,  although  Dalanzadgad  has  a  large  power  station  operated  by  the  Ministry  of  Mineral 
Resources  and  Energy,  and  most  gers,  houses,  and  all  apartments  have  power  connections.  Of  the 
smaller towns, Gurvan Tes is connected to a 6,000 kilovolt line built by Qinhua MAK mining company, 
which  imports  power  from  the  PRC.  In  Tsogttsetsii  and  Hanbogd  the  power  supply  is  met  through 
diesel  generators  and  is  only  provided  for  a  few  hours  per  day  due  to  lack  of  fuel.  Street  lighting  is 
provided by the soums where power is available.  

12. 
Only  the  three  larger  towns  have  surfaced  intra-urban  roads,  restricted  to  the  formal  central 
areas.  The  three  smaller  towns  are  served  only  by  dirt  roads,  and  there  are  no  continuous  asphalt 
concrete  roads  linking  any  of  the  towns  or  linking  them  to  Ulaanbaatar,  although  Zamyn-Uud  has  an 
asphalt concrete road linking it to the PRC.  

13. 
The frequency and extent of solid-waste collection varies across the towns. In the formal areas, 
collection  is  daily  or  biweekly,  with  some  areas  also  having  communal  containers.  In  the  ger  areas, 
collection  is  less  frequent  and  in  the  small  towns  it  may  be  carried  out  only  once  or  twice  every 
3 months. All towns have garbage disposal sites, some of which are fenced, although none are close to 
being considered sanitary landfills. Recycling is carried out informally, apart from Dalanzadgad where 
there  is  a  public  utility  services  organization  (PUSO)-operated  recycling  yard.  The  seminomadic 
lifestyles of the ger dwellers mean that not much waste is generated and significant in-house recycling, 
or use of waste for fuel, takes place.  

14. 
The aimag and soum governments are responsible for service provision, including water supply, 
wastewater management, district heating, and solid-waste management (in some aimags). These are 
provided through PUSOs which were created from various enterprises established to provide services 
under  the  previous  communist  system.  The  PUSOs  were  meant  to  be  self-financing,  but  they  have 
difficulty  in  setting  cost-recovery  tariffs  since  revisions  to  existing  tariff  require  approval  of  aimag 
governments. Mini-PUSOs or heating companies operating in the small towns in Omnogovi do so quite 
independently of the PUSO and are regulated by an aimag coordination committee. In Dornogovi, the 
institutional  arrangements  for  service  delivery  have  developed  in  a  more  ad  hoc  manner.  As  both 
Saynshand and Zamyn-Uud initially developed in the 1950s as railway townships, the railway company 
provided  all  the  municipal  services.  As  both  towns  grew,  a  parallel  local  government  was  created  to 
supply  services  to  the nonrailway  township,  and  currently  infrastructure and  services  are  provided  by 
both  the  railway  company  and  the  PUSOs,  although  the  railway  company  is  prepared  to  transfer  its 
assets for operation by the PUSO.

DEVELOPMENT COORDINATION 
 

Major Development Partners: Strategic Focus and Key Activities  

A. 
 
Several development partners are active in the urban sector in Mongolia, notably the World 
1. 
Bank  (integrated  urban  development,  ger  [traditional  felt  tent]  area  development,  and  urban  air 
quality), Japan International Cooperation Agency (water supply, and urban planning and transport 
in  Ulaanbaatar),  and  German  development  cooperation  through  GTZ  (urban  environment  and 
energy  efficiency).  The  World  Bank  prepared  the  Southern  Mongolia  Infrastructure  Strategy1 in 
2008–2009,  which  focused  on  infrastructure  and  institutional  needs  in  Omnogovi  and  brought 
stakeholders together to discuss these. It is preparing a technical assistance project that will seek 
to  stimulate  private  investment  to  support  mining  activities  and  build  local  capacity  to  prepare 
transactions for private sector participation in infrastructure. 
 
2. 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is supporting several ongoing and planned activities in 
Southeast Gobi. About $1.3 million has gone into rehabilitating basic urban services in Saynshand 
and Dalanzadgad. More than $1 million has been invested in Omnogovi aimag (province) and $0.5 
million in Dornogovi aimag in rehabilitating schools, providing textbooks and tool kits, and training 
teachers;  $1.3 million  has  been  invested  in  Dornogovi  aimag  in  rehabilitating  and  constructing 
aimag  and  soum  (district)  hospitals,  capacity  building  and  training,  and  providing  medical 
equipment  and  motorbikes.  In  2009  an  advisory  technical  assistance  project  started  which  is 
supporting HIV/AIDS Prevention in ADB Infrastructure Projects and the Mining Sector. Also in 2009, 
an ADB-financed project preparatory technical assistance project is supporting the development of 
the Regional Logistics Development Project for trade logistics facilities at Zamyn-Uud.

Groundwater Monitoring in Southeast Gobi 

 
B. 
 
3. 
Southeast  Gobi  is  largely  arid  and  its  population  centers  depend  entirely  on  groundwater 
from  shallow  aquifers.  Mining  companies  have  developed  bore  fields  to  exploit  deep  aquifers  for 
industrial use near Tsogttsetsii and Hanbogd, and plan to provide bulk water to the local population. 
Based  on  studies  undertaken  by  two  private  mining  companies  (Ivanhoe  Mines  and  Energy 
Resources,  the  deep  aquifers  they  will  tap  for  industrial  needs  are  not  linked  with  the  shallow 
aquifers accessed by existing and proposed wells to provide potable supplies.  
 
4. 
Despite  indications  that  there  is  no  linkage  between  shallow  and  deep  aquifers  in  this 
region, the importance of these resources for sustainable development underscores the need for a 
viable  groundwater  monitoring  system.  The  World  Bank  is  initiating  work  on  new  institutional 
arrangements  for  groundwater  monitoring,  which  by  the  end  of  2010  will  prepare  a  groundwater 
management  plan  for  the  South  Gobi  hydrological  region  (which  includes  Omnogovi  and 
Dornogovi),  develop  a  framework  for  integrated  groundwater  management,  advise  on  requisite 
policy  and  legislative  needs  and  the  establishment  of  a  new  groundwater  management  center  in 
the region in 2011. In 2010 Oyu Tolgoi (the company that is developing and mining the Oyu Tolgoi 
copper deposit) will begin a substantial groundwater monitoring program in the area near Hanbogd 
and  has  committed  to  an  approach  that  involves  local  stakeholders  and  ensures  transparency. 
Energy Resources is expected to implement a similar groundwater monitoring program in the area 
near Tavan Tolgoi and around points of groundwater abstraction commencing in 2010.  
 

 

 38  

Appendix 3 

 

Institutional Arrangements and Processes for Development Coordination  

A groundwater monitoring system is needed to ensure that information about the impact of 
5. 
abstraction  by  the  mining  industry  can  be  used  in  environmental  planning,  future  mining 
development, pasture management, and urban development. The initiatives of the World Bank and 
mining companies will together address this need across Southeast Gobi. Review missions for the 
proposed  project  will  address  the  issue  on  a  regular  basis.  The  project  management  unit  will 
ensure  coordination  with  the  National  Water  Committee  and  any  future  water  resources 
management agency.  
 
As part of due diligence, the project will establish sustainable groundwater yields of water 
6. 
supply  wells,  confirm  absence  of  conflicts  between  existing  water  users,  conduct  testing  and 
analysis  of  drinking  water  quality,  and  obtain  water  extraction  and  development  permits,  as 
necessary. 
 
C. 
 
7. 
Key  development  partners  engaged  in  the  urban  sector  (including  the  Japan  International 
Cooperation  Agency,  German  development  cooperation  through  GTZ,  and  the  World  Bank)  are 
members  of  the  Urban  Development  Working  Group  (UDWG)  whose  mandate  is  to  facilitate 
dialogue  and  coordinate  assistance.  The  UDWG  is  chaired  by  the  minister  of  roads,  transport, 
construction and urban development, and cochaired by the governments of Germany and Japan. It 
meets on a quarterly basis. Development partners also coordinate bilaterally and multilaterally on 
specific  subsector  issues,  such  as  urban  planning  for  Ulaanbaatar,  or  water  sector  reform  and 
regulation. 
 
D. 
 
8. 
Through  bilateral  coordination  and  the  UDWG  mechanism,  development  partners  have 
achieved  a  consensus  on  the  need  for  improved  urban  planning  and  reform  of  key  municipal 
services.  Furthermore,  there  is  effective  coordination  regarding  subsector  priorities  and  activities. 
An  example  of  this  has  been  seen  in  the  closely  coordinated  and  interlinked  activities  of  ADB, 
World  Bank,  the  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development,  and  the  Millennium 
Challenge  Corporation  in  addressing  air  pollution  in  Ulaanbaatar.  In  Omnogovi,  the  World  Bank 
and ADB have had frequent dialogue concerning regional planning, groundwater management and 
monitoring, infrastructure needs, and policy reform.

41 

 

PROJECT MANAGEMENT, ORGANIZATIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND CAPACITY BUILDING  

1. 
The  project  places  local  governments  at  the  center  of  project  implementation.  At  present 
the  capacity  of  both  aimag  (province)  and  soum  (district)  governments  to  respond  to  citizen’s 
demands, and initiate, plan, deliver, and manage urban infrastructure development and improved 
service  delivery,  is  limited.  Local  governments  have  limited  financial  and  technical  resources,  an 
absence of systems, few staff, and inadequate capacity to effectively carry out these tasks. At the 
same  time,  although  the  executing  agency—the  Ministry  of  Roads,  Transport,  Construction  and 
Urban  Development—has  experience  in  the  execution  of  urban  development  projects,  it  has 
previously performed as both executing and implementing agency, delivering completed projects to 
local  governments  and  providing  little  in  the  way  of  technical  assistance,  capacity  building,  or 
training  to  assist  local  governments  to  develop  their  own  urban  planning  and  management 
capability.  The  project  needs  to support  a  shift  in  responsibility  for  urban  planning, management, 
and  delivery  of  local  infrastructure  from  the  national  government  to  local  governments,  with  the 
ministry moving to a regulatory, facilitating, and supporting role in the sector.  

2. 
The quality, coverage, and reliability of service delivery at the aimag level are constrained 
by existing service delivery arrangements. The public urban service organizations (PUSOs) are just 
coping  in  maintaining  existing  levels  of  service  and  are  not  in  a  position  to  expand  service 
coverage  to  meet  expected  demand  for  services  and  infrastructure.  They  are  guided  by 
management contracts that lack specificity on service quality and coverage, dispute resolution, and 
remuneration;  struggle  to  recover  operating  and  maintenance  costs;  and  lack  access  to  training 
and  managerial  expertise.  The  most  fundamental  constraint  is  low  tariffs;  PUSOs’  requests  for 
increases to enable routine operating and maintenance costs to be recovered are often rejected by 
the aimag Citizens' Representatives Khural1 due to the political unpopularity of such adjustments. 
The  project  presents  an  opportunity  to  introduce  fundamental  changes  to  the  institutional 
framework  for  municipal  service  provision  and  its  regulation  through  (i)  divesting  all  or  part  of 
PUSOs  so  as  to  decouple  service  providers  from  local  government  administration  and  attract 
private  capital  and  expertise;  (ii)  introducing  an  operating  management  contract  that  provides 
performance-based  incentives  for  the  service  provider;  and  (iii)  establishing  a  regulatory 
mechanism  at  a  central  level,  which  links  tariffs  with  the  prices  of  key  inputs  and  avoids  political 
involvement in tariff setting.  

To  support  this  institutional  development  and  reform,  it  is  proposed  under  part  A  of  the 
3. 
project to use the project itself as a vehicle to bring about this change. The proposed project thus 
adopts  a  “drivers  of  change”-type  of  approach, whereby  the  reform  and  institutional  development 
actions  required  to  underpin  the  execution  of  the  sector  road  map,  and  thus  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB)-supported project, form an integral part of the project itself. It is intended 
that  execution  of  the  project  will  help  to  drive  change  in  policy  areas  that  are  closely  related  to 
project  execution—the  role  of  national  and  local  government  in  urban  development,  urban 
planning, service delivery, and local government finance—in addition to project management and 
supervision. 

4.

training  to  both  national  and  local  governments  to  (i)  ensure  effective  project  execution  and 
implementation  (including  project  benefit  evaluation  and  monitoring);  (ii)  build  local  government 
capacity  in  urban  governance,  planning,  development  and  management,  and  sustainable  service 
delivery; (iii) build urban planning capacity at national and local levels and support preparation of 
structure plans for the project towns; (iv) provide transaction advice for the tendering of operating 
management contracts for urban service delivery, and in establishing a regulator; and (v) ensuring

recommendations 

Project  management  support  to  the  executing  agency  (MRTCUD)  and  implementing 
agencies  (aimag  and  soum  governments  and  service  companies).  The  consultants 
would  be  located  within  both  the  PMU  and  PIUs  and  take  responsibility  for  assisting 
government in timely project execution and implementation, and on-the-job and formal 
training in matters relating to project design, procurement, management, operation, and 
maintenance. The activities covered would include project management and monitoring; 
implementation  planning;  ensuring  reference  designs  are  prepared  and  approved; 
assisting  the  PIU  in  procurement  of  goods,  works  and  services,  monitoring,  and 
supervision; ensuring compliance with project safeguards and covenants; and assisting 
in establishing the sustainability of the project outputs. At the PIU level, activities would 
include  supervising  the  preparation  of  reference  designs  and  tender  documents; 
assisting  with  tender  evaluation  and  award;  project  progress  and  contract  monitoring; 
and reporting to the aimag governments, project working groups, and PMU.

guide  policy,  facilitate,  support,  regulate,  and  provide  standards  for  urban  local 
governments.  Organizational  and  capacity  development  support  will  be  provided  to 
equip  the  department  to  discharge  these  functions.  Carry  out  review  and  functional 
assessments of project aimags with respect to their planning and development functions 
and where appropriate, develop proposals for organizational restructuring. Prepare job

Under Part A of the Project: Package A.2 Support to Urban Service Company Reform and Regulation  
5. Support to 
Assistance  will  be  provided  in  the  creation  of  new  arrangements  for  the  provision  of 
urban  services  in  Omnogovi  and  Dornogovi  aimags  under  operating  management 
contracts to include (i) confirming the structure of the proposed new service companies; 
(ii)  developing  the  necessary  documentation  for  tender,  evaluation,  and  issue  of  the 
operating  management  contract;  and  (iii)  managing  the  transaction  to  enable  the 
contracts  to  be  let  between  the  two  aimag  governments  of  Omnogovi  and  Dornogovi 
and  urban  service  companies.  The  operating  management  contracts  will  cover  the 
operation  and  management  of  municipal  water  supply,  wastewater  management, 
heating, and solid-waste management services in the project aimag and soum centers. 
The operating management contract will cover operation and management of both new 
and  existing  infrastructure  systems,  including  those  which  will  be  transferred  from  the 
ownership of the Ulaanbaatar Tumur Zam railway company to Dornogovi aimag.  
Assistance to the government in (i) determining the location of the new regulator within 
(or  outside  of)  government;  (ii)  identifying  skills  and  resources  required  to  fulfill 
regulatory functions in the urban service sectors; (iii) developing organizational charts, 
or, as appropriate, amended institutional charts of host existing institution; (iv) providing 
job  descriptions  for  new  positions,  or  amended  job  descriptions  as  appropriate;  (v) 
preparing a draft budget for the regulator (or an incremental budget as appropriate); (vi) 
preparing  the  founding  documents  for  the  new  regulator  (a  charter  and  articles  of 
incorporation),  or  any  changes  to  existing  laws  or  founding  documents  required  to 
absorb the new responsibilities for service regulation; and (vii) developing a training and 
capacity building program.

Appendix 7 

 

PROJECT EXECUTION AND IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS 

 
1. 
The Ministry of Road, Transportation, Construction and Urban Development (MRTCUD) 
will  be  the  executing  agency,  supported  by  a  project  management  unit  (PMU)  headed  by  a 
project  director.  The  MRTCUD  will  be  responsible  for  overall  strategic  guidance,  technical 
supervision, and execution of the project and ensuring compliance with grant covenants. A state 
project  steering  committee  (PSC)  will  be  set  up  with  full  powers  to  take  decisions  on  matters 
relating  to  project  execution.  The  project  director  will  be  the  member  secretary  and  the 
committee will be chaired by the state secretary of the MRTCUD. Members of the committee will 
include the chair of the National Development and Innovation Committee (NDIC), director of the 
Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF),  representatives  of  the  ministries  of  environment  and  mineral 
resources  and  energy  and  the  aimag  (province)  governments  of  Dornogovi  and  Omnogovi. 
Once the project is made effective, the PSC will meet at least once every 3 months to review 
project  performance  and  take  decisions  on  major  issues,  such  as  counterpart  funding, 
implementation bottlenecks, land disputes, special procurement, and policy reforms. 
 
The PMU will be responsible for (i) appointing project management consultants, detailed 
2. 
design,  and  construction  supervision  consultants;  (ii)  approving  the  design  of  the  investment 
components  in  consultation  with  the  aimag  government  and  project  towns;  (iii)  assisting  the 
project implementation units (PIU), which will be formed at aimag level to implement the project, 
in preparing standard bid documents, monitoring the tendering process, and guiding the project 
towns  in  bid  evaluation  and  preparation  of  bid  evaluation  reports  for  approval  by  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB);  (iv)  coordinating  with  ADB  on  matters  related  to  disbursement;  (v) 
monitoring  compliance  with  grant  covenants;  (vi)  supervising  project  benefit  monitoring  and 
evaluation;  and  (vii)  maintaining  project  documentation  and  submitting  timely  reports  to  ADB. 
The PMU will be supported by consultants. 
 
3. 
The  project  director,  supported  by  the  PMU  and  its  consultants,  will  coordinate  all 
activities  under  the  project;  be  responsible  for  overall  project  execution,  monitoring,  and 
supervision; and will directly report to the chair of the PSC.  
 
4. 
Implementation  of  part  A  of  the  project  will  be  managed  by  the  MRTCUD  through  the 
PMU  and  with  assistance  from  the  PMU  management  support  consultants.  Implementation  of 
the urban environmental improvement component (part B) will be carried out by the participating 
aimag governments with assistance from the MRTCUD. At aimag level, the MRTCUD will set up 
PIUs in each aimag center, headed by a senior technical officer as the PIU project director. The 
director will be responsible for the day-to-day implementation of the respective physical works 
packages. The MRTCUD will coordinate the activities of the two PIUs at the aimag level through 
management consultants and PMU staff, and will facilitate processing and approvals of designs, 
contracts,  and  other  documents  as  required  at  ministry  level.  The  PMU  and  PIUs  will  be 
properly  staffed  and  assisted  by  consultants  with  expertise  in  engineering,  finance  and 
accounting, social and gender development, institutional development, community development, 
procurement,  resettlement,  and  urban  planning.  This  will  include  environmental  management 
consultants and environmental safeguard specialist who will ensure revised and expanded IEEs 
and  EMPs  are  prepared  during  detailed  engineering  design.  The  refined  EMPs  and  the  GRM 
will be made available to the affected persons.  
 
5. 
In each aimag, the PIU will comprise three sections: (i) urban infrastructure and services, 
(ii)  community  awareness  and  participation,  and  (iii)  finance  and  administration.  With  the 
assistance of consultants, the responsibilities of the PIUs shall include (i) carrying out detailed 
surveys, investigations, and reference designs of the subprojects; (ii) preparing bid documents, 

 

 Appendix 7 

47 

 

tendering,  evaluating  bids,  and  awarding  works;  (iii)  contract  administration,  supervision  and 
quality control, measurement of works carried out by the contractors, and certifying payments; 
(iv) conducting public awareness campaigns and participation programs; (v) benefit monitoring 
and  evaluation  studies  and  environmental  assessment;  (vi) implementing  resettlement  plans; 
and  (vii)  preparing  monthly  reports  to  the  PMU  and  aimag  governments.  Aimag  governments 
will  implement  the  subprojects  with  technical  assistance  from  the  both  the  PIU  and  the  public 
urban service organization.  
 
The progress of the project and performance of each PIU will be monitored and guided 
6. 
by  aimag  working  groups  chaired  by  the  aimag  governors.  The  working  groups  will  comprise 
representatives  from  the  aimag  government,  soum  (district)  governors,  PIUs,  public  urban 
service  organizations 
(or  urban  services  companies),  participating  community-based 
organizations,  and  civil  society  representatives  to  include  some  prominent  citizens.  Once  the 
project  is  made  effective,  the  aimag  working  group  will  meet  at  least  once  every  3  months  to 
review project progress and resolve local issues and policy matters.

arrangements and the flow of funding under the project.

lessee,  will  be  displaced;  two  households  on  the  other  two  plots  will  lose  land  partially,  and  two 
lessees on the other two plots will be relocated. No productive assets and income sources are lost. 
The estimated number of persons affected by this priority infrastructure improvement is 26 from a 
total of seven households. The land acquisition and resettlement plan (LARP) is in Supplementary 
Appendix N. 
 
2. 
Of  a  total  of  seven  households,  two  households  will  each  lose  their  entire  750  square 
meters  (m2)  of  owned  land  and  will  be  allocated  land  on-site  (close  to  existing  plots).  One 
household will lose one-third of owned land and will be compensated equivalent to the size of the 
land to be acquired. One household that occupies a 1,232 m2 plot (out of which 166 m2 or 13% is 
nontitled)  will  lose  the  nontitled  land.  In  terms  of  structures,  five  gers  (traditional  felt  tents),  six 
sheds, and 237 meters of wooden fence will be permanently displaced. Owners and lessees who 
need to relocate their gers and other light structures shall be provided with financial assistance. All 
affected households will be compensated in accordance with the entitlement matrix in the LARP.  
 
Compensation to the affected persons will be paid in full prior to the possession of the land 
3. 
and the award of civil works contracts. A resettlement budget of $53,086 including contingencies is 
provided. An implementation schedule indicates milestones within an approximate time frame.  
 
Information  dissemination  and  consultation  has  already  begun  and  will  continue.  All 
4. 
affected household heads participated in a consultation meeting on 7 June 2009 held in Hanbogd. 
This was followed by individual meetings and interviews with affected persons. The contents of the 
LARP were discussed. The LARP has been translated into Mongolian and made available at the 
soum (district) governor’s office in Hanbogd for public reference. A grievance redress mechanism 
has been stipulated in the LARP and was explained to the affected persons during the consultation 
meetings.

implementation;  (ii)  submit  reports

While no additional land acquisition and resettlement impacts are expected in other priority 
infrastructure  improvements  under  the  project,  the  rapid  population  influx  and  economic 
development in the project area raises the possibility that unforeseen impacts may occur. For this 
reason, a land acquisition and resettlement framework (LARF), prepared in accordance with ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement,1 has been prepared and is in Supplementary Appendix M.  
 
The  LARF’s  provisions  and  stipulations  are  applicable  to  all  project  components.  It 
9. 
establishes a policy framework for compensation eligibility and entitlements for all types of affected 
persons. It outlines the necessary steps to prepare satisfactory LARPs for project components that 
have  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  impacts  and  stipulates  arrangements  for  consultation  and 
public participation, grievance redress, and monitoring and evaluation. 
 
10. 
Land acquisition and resettlement by the government for local-scale projects in urban areas 
is  based  on  negotiation  and  contracts  with  affected  persons  according  to  the  Civil  Code  of 
Mongolia.  The  ADB  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  recognizes  negotiated  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement  as  long  as  there  are  willing  and  free  buyers  and  sellers,  and  eligibility  and 
entitlements  are  clearly  defined  and  agreed.  All  affected  persons  are  eligible  for  entitlements,  as 
stipulated in the LARF for the project, including owners, possessors, users, legalizable occupants, 
nontitled occupants and lessees. The eviction of unlicensed affected persons is a violation of the 
ADB  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  All  affected  persons  who  are  unlicensed  occupants  of  land  in 
ger areas designated for land allocation are treated as legalizable under the LARF for the project.

LARF.

Country and Project Title: Mongolia: Southeast Gobi Urban and Border Town Development Project

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 

The  project  has  been  identified  and  prepared  based  on  (i)  the  National  Development  Strategy  and  ADB-supported  urban 
sector  road  map;  (ii)  the  World  Bank-supported  report  on  the  Southern  Mongolia  Infrastructure  Strategy  (and  particularly 
sections on Housing and Urban Infrastructure); (iii) the government’s development plans for the infrastructure development  
in  Southern  Gobi  prepared  by  the  NDIC;  (iv)  planned  logistics  infrastructure  development  at  Zamyn-Uud  and  other  border 
crossings;  (v)  the  Land  Management  Plan  for  the  “Galbyn  Gobi”  micro-regional  development  concept  prepared  under  the 
guidance of the MRTCUD; (vi) urban development master plans and investment plans prepared for aimag centers and key 
soum  centers  in  the  region;  and  (vii)  meetings  and  workshops  with  government  officials,  the  private  sector,  and  other 
stakeholders including town residents. 

An urban development plan for the subregion has been prepared  which sets out the development goals and objectives for 
urban development in 2010-2015, and identifies investments to achieve these objectives. Based on the plan, an institutional 
reform  and  development  framework  has  been  developed  which  will  support  effective  planning,  financing,  and  operation  of 
urban  infrastructure  and  services.  This  sets  out  specific  reforms,  associated  capacity  development,  and  a  timetable  for 
implementation.  Emphasis  is  placed  on  (i)  improving  local  governance  and  urban  planning  and  management  capacity,  (ii) 
improving  the  institutional  and  contractual  arrangements  for  service  provision,  (iii)  enhancing  urban  planning  systems  and 
capacities at national and local levels, and (iv) minimizing recurrent expenditures and establishing clear accountability for the 
performance of contractors and service providers. 

The  project  is  designed  to  have  multidimensional  impacts  on  poverty  reduction  by  improving  infrastructure  and  services, 
reducing time spent in water collection, creating direct employment for construction and indirect long-term income-generating 
opportunities,  and  empowering  poor  residents  in  decision-making  processes  through  improved  urban  governance.  The 
project  will  have  positive  health  benefits.  Residents  are  expected  to  experience  a  reduction  in  the  incidence  of  water-  and 
vector-borne diseases and medical costs, and lost earning opportunities incurred as a result of these diseases.  

It is anticipated that the sector reforms  will result in tariff increases for  water supply,  wastewater management, and  district 
heating in order to enable the service providers to recover sufficient costs to cover operational expenditures. The impact of 
tariff increases on the poor is not serious because (i) financial analysis shows that increased tariffs would still remain within 
affordability  and  willingness-to-pay  levels;  and  (ii)  the  poor  live  predominantly  in  ger  areas,  which  do  not  benefit  from 
sewerage or district heating, and where potable water is carried from water kiosks, resulting in low levels of consumption.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification:  General Intervention 
 
Key  issues. The project is primarily designed to improve the urban infrastructure and services of selected aimag and soum 
centers in Dornogovi and Omnogovi aimags. The key focus of the project will be to provide urban infrastructure and services 
to  the  project  aimag  and  soum  centers  to  improve  the  quality,  reliability,  and  coverage  of  urban  services  to  existing 
communities and to serve incoming populations.  
 
All the soum centers are projected to experience a significant influx of people, mostly driven by the growth of mining jobs and 
associated  infrastructure  in  the  area,  and  the  resulting  growth  in  cross-border  trade  with  the  PRC.  Consequently,  existing 
urban infrastructure and services, which are already deficient, will become still less adequate. Population expansion will lead 
to growth in service industries provided that barriers to access to job opportunities are removed. 

The  project  thus  aims  to  improve  urban  infrastructure  and  service  provision  so  as  to  contribute  toward  the  overall 
enhancement of urban service quality and coverage in the soum centers. The project will contribute to improved access to 
services and better quality of life for the project beneficiaries, thereby alleviating those aspects of human poverty.  

Design  features.  It  is  anticipated  that  the  sector  reforms  will  result  in  tariff  increases  for  water  supply,  wastewater 
management,  and  district  heating  to  enable  the  service  providers  to  recover  sufficient  costs  to  cover  operational 
expenditures.  The  poor  live  predominantly  in  ger  areas,  which  do  not  have  sewerage  or  district  heating  services.  Potable 
water is carried from water kiosks, the number of which will be increased under part B of the project, thus reducing the time 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 Appendix 12 

57 

 

 

taken to collect water.     
 
A  community  consultation  and  participation  framework  has  been  prepared  for  the  project  to  ensure  the  participation  of  the 
community, including women, in project planning and implementation. Contacts and dialogue with the beneficiaries built up 
during the public consultation phase can be used as a basis to form infrastructure project implementation committees (one 
per soum center). The composition of these committees will include equal numbers of working-age women and men and will 
include representatives from low-income households. 
 

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 

Key  issues. The key  poverty aspect  which  is applicable in the urban context focuses on deprivation through limited  or no 
access to basic urban services. The infrastructure improvements made under this project include new or improved access to 
drinking  water,  district  heating,  sewerage,  electricity,  solid-waste  management,  and  secondary  paved  roads.  Each 
beneficiary community includes low-income households.   
 
Residents  living  in  gers  and  some  houses  who  will  not  be  connected  to  piped  services  will  nonetheless  benefit  from  the 
improvements  to  public  health  brought  about  by  water  supply  improvements  through  kiosks,  and  improved  sanitation  in 
schools,  clinics,  and  other  institutions. The  entire  population  will  benefit  from  a  cleaner  and  less  dusty  urban  environment. 
Improved  services  will  also  help  stimulate  business  growth  and  income  generation,  provided  that  the  safeguards  of 
vocational  training  are  also  implemented.  Forty  two  project  components  have  been  prepared  in  the  aimag  centers  of 
Dalanzadgad and Saynshand, and in the soum centers of Zamyn-Uud, Gurvantes, Tsogttsetsii, and Hanbogd. 

B.  Consultation and Participation  

 
Consultation and participation during project implementation and monitoring will involve the following:

Was a C&P plan prepared? 
 
 Project  stakeholders  include  the  central  and  local  governments;  institutions  such  as  schools,  kindergartens,  and  clinics; 
beneficiary populations living in apartments, houses, and gers; and small-business proprietors and future mining employees 
who will live in the project areas. During project preparation, discussions were undertaken with project beneficiaries. Particular 
attention was paid to ensuring participation of residents of the various dwelling types (some living in formal areas with access 
to  a  range  of  network  services,  others  living  in  informal  ger  areas  with  limited  access  to  services)  and  which  have 
socioeconomically vulnerable households headed by women and other low-income households, so as to receive their views 
and opinions on the project.  
 
The  primary  aim  of  all  these  discussions  was  to  (i)  inform  the  communities  and  population  about  the  proposed  project 
intervention;  (ii)  get  a  better  understanding  of  the  prevailing  conditions  and  coping  mechanisms  related  to  access  to  urban 
services, in particular in relation to the poor and to women; and (iii) get wider public input and suggestions from stakeholders 
on the project intervention, particularly the priority and levels of affordability with regard to the infrastructure offered.  
 
These discussions and consultations confirmed the need for the project. There was a positive response from all stakeholders 
among  all  socioeconomic  groups  toward  the  project.  The  key  benefits  of  the  project  as  voiced  by  the  stakeholders  are  (i) 
better service provision will reduce drudgery involved in collecting water for drinking, cooking, and hygiene, particularly in the 
case of  women and children; (ii) improved  sewage disposal  and  waste  management will support increased cleanliness and 
hygiene,  and  reduced  waterborne  diseases  in  institutions  and  in  the  home;  (iii)  other  services  will  provide  improved  urban 
amenity  and  living  conditions,  and  a  healthier  and  less  dusty  public  environment;  and  (iv)  improved  heating  will  lead  to 
increased productivity within dwellings.  
 
Future  public  consultations  and  disclosure  will  be  held  during  detailed  engineering  design,  construction,  and  operational 
stages. The PMU, PIUs, and soum project inspectors  will be responsible for addressing any concerns and issues raised by 
project  beneficiary  communities,  regular  meetings  with  infrastructure  project  implementation  committees,  and  instituting  the 
necessary changes or additions in project management and environmental or social mitigation measures. These shall follow 
the general guidelines of (i) all stakeholders should be invited and encouraged to participate in the consultation  workshops; 
(ii) suggestions from the general public may  be sought  through the mass  media,  when necessary; and  (iii) the PIUs,  aimag 
and soum project and environmental inspectors, contractor, and/or operator should meet with and be responsive to the public 
on matters concerning the progress of the projects, adverse social or environmental impacts, effective mitigation measures, 
and quality of monitoring and supervision.

Information  disclosed  to  date  includes  project  objectives  and  components;  proposed  subprojects  and  subcomponents; 
proposed  implementation  arrangements;  and  environmental,  social,  land  acquisition,  and  resettlement  requirements  of  the 
project following the disclosure and safeguard policies of the Government of Mongolia and the ADB. 
 
Future  public  consultation  will  include  involvement  in  monitoring  impacts  and  mitigation  measures  during  construction  and 
operation, evaluating environmental and economic benefits and social impacts, and interviewing the public after the project is 
completed.  The  soum  and  aimag  governments  will  establish  and  operate  a  social  and  environmental  complaints  and 
grievance  procedure  to  facilitate  the  identification  and  resolution  of  project  implementation  issues  that  concern  the 
beneficiaries or any affected person. 
 

C.   Gender and Development 

Key  issues. To understand gender-specific roles, gender status, needs, and problems within the selected aimag and soum 
centers,  a  process  of  female  and  male  focus  group  consultations  was  undertaken.  These  comprised  women  and  men 
belonging  to  various  socioeconomic  categories  in  the  subproject  areas.  The  topics  discussed  included  the  likely  gender 
impacts of the project in terms of women’s and men’s traditional roles. Future employment expectations were also discussed. 
These discussions aimed to capture  women’s and men’s collective perceptions about social, economic, and cultural norms; 
their ability to access and afford the future new services; and prospects for future employment in their areas.  
 
The discussions with the women indicated that the improvements to urban services, particularly water supply and heating, will 
have significant positive  impacts in relieving the burden of housework,  while at the  same time freeing  up time to  engage  in 
other of income-generating activities. This requires certain measures to be put in place, including (i) water supply and other 
municipal services which would give women more time for productive endeavors, empowerment activities, and leisure; and (ii) 
improvements to heating which would improve their mobility and productivity within their dwellings in winter.   
 
The men were interested in increased income-generation potential that improved water supply and other services will bring. In 
particular, opportunities for horticulture and a variety of workshop activities will be increased. 
 
The  forecast  rapid  population  influx,  initially  of  unaccompanied  men,  brought  about  by  the  new  economic  development, 
(although  not  directly  resulting  from  this  project),  has  potential  negative  impacts,  particularly  on  women.  Project  measures 
have  been  formulated  to  ensure  that  absorptive  capacity  of  project  benefits  by  women  will  not  decrease.  For  example, 
vocational training and HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention will be provided under part A to (i) protect adolescent women and 
low-income or unskilled women from being forced into prostitution and cross-border trafficking; and (ii) ensure that women will 
be  able  to  take  advantage  of  the  new  amenities  and  business  opportunities  directly  and  indirectly  afforded  by  project 
improvements.  
 
Key  actions.  Measures are included in the design to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment—access to and 
use  of  relevant  services,  resources,  assets,  or  opportunities;  participation  in  decision-making  process;  and  access  to 
employment and training activities. A gender action plan has been prepared with key actions to ensure and measure women's 
participation  in  decision  making  and  consultation.  Implementation  of  the  gender  action  plan,  which  is  included  as  an 
assurance, will be the responsibility of the PMU which will work with the PIUs to measure indicators and achieve targets. The 
Mongolia Resident Mission gender specialist will support PMU and PIU staff during implementation.
